But, I also like that it's connected to Paris so you don't have to go out in the blistering heat.  All in all, I thoroughly enjoyed my stay at Bally's and would be more than happy to stay here again!
Horrible customer service.  In new towers 2 of 3 elevators didn't work.  Old towers run down.  NEEDS WORK

Oh Mikey you don't want all that 'Pirates Of The Caribbean' horseshit, or the 'Rock & Roll on the Grunge Tip.' Guys like you and me gotta kick it here, old school." -- Trent (Swingers) 

Find another place where you are still in "Classic Vegas," and have that ABSOLUTE direct access to every other awesome spot on the strip...

Centered at the heart of the strip, on the corner of Flamingo Rd. and Las Vegas Blvd. sits Bally's which has remained classic for the last 20+ years... sure it's older, but it's still fun, clean, historic and most of all a classy place... and again -- centered in the middle of all the action on the foremost corner on the strip, right across from Caesar's (my favorite place to play!).

If you're going to Vegas with a few friends or for a day or two, sure blow your wad and pile into a nice room at the Wynn, The Cosmopolitan, Bellagio, etc... but if you're the type that likes to lay back and really do Vegas for a few days or a week... and the type that likes to be able to relax when it's time to turn in at the end of an 18hr day that included some severe table games, smoking premium cigars at Casa Fuente, chatting it up with tourists, hitting the sports book, dancing, eating at buffets, shopping, drinking drinking drinking, and walking up and down the strip and playing at EVERY CASINO... then opt for Ballys. 

Hey, it's quaint, and there's not a lot of frills or gorgeous giant golden chandeliers with rubies and emeralds hanging from it, or even those nifty water spouts that shoot water into holes carved out into the wall across the room, but again, IT'S CLASSIC VEGAS and priced amazingly for the amount of accessibility, the cleanliness, and awesome location on the strip. And did I mention, the employees and front desk has always been helpful and sweet to me?

I usually enjoy saving that extra three to eight hundred bucks (depending on length of stay) over the other high-end spots on the strip (which are sometimes placed in less-desirable locations IMHO), and then using that cash as much-needed spending money for: big tips, fun table games, classy drinks, random shopping (have to shop in Vegas!), and of course the delicious eats + cab fare... 

Most of the folks kicking 1-3 stars to Ballys should stick to The Cosmo and the Wynn, where they can go to The Marquee and hit up XS, respectively... or maybe pile into a suite at the Hard Rock where they can blow their allowance at some densely packed and over-tanned pool party... but for true old school cats like myself who fancy a nice sitting at the Galleria Bar @ Caesar's and hitting up some Chinese dinner on the waterfront @ The Bellagio... along with some great seats to an awesome show, well, I'm beyond-fine with laying my head here at Ballys at the end of the night (morning)... especially at the rates for Total Rewards members.

*I should note, I don't play a lot at Ballys, and I've only stayed in the rooms in the newer North Tower, haven't seen the older ones, so definitely opt for an upgrade if you can. I also consider myself lucky, because I've never received anything but great service from the front desk and have often been upgraded to rooms facing the strip, right over all the neon walkways with watershow views... for the same rate. In this town, a little respect goes a long ways :)

Thanks Ballys

It is a good clean hotel with very professional staff. The only thing I was disappointed is the view from my window. When I reserved the room I  picked the room with a pretty view  on the city but unfortunately  when I opened the door I saw the view on a parking lot. Next time I will try something else.

Bally's is getting a 4 star rating vs. a 5 just because it desperately needs a refresh. The room was great including the bathroom and the insulation was awesome we heard no noise not even from the street and we were on the 5th floor. There was no smell of smoke in the elevators, halls or room, and the smell in the casino was only strong when you were near someone smoking so good job Bally's.

I recently stayed 5 nights at Bally's when I was in town with 30 co-workers for the HIMSS conference. It's conveniently located on the strip right next to Paris, which is also connected to, and accessible from Bally's. I had a renovated room with 2 queen beds, a desk, a TV, and modern-looking furniture and accoutrements. The electrical outlets could have been more conveniently placed, the pillows weren't fantastic, and I could have used an extra blanket, but otherwise, the room was fine. I recommend requesting one of the newly renovated rooms though. Most of my co-workers were in older rooms and would have offered a 2 or 3 star based on complaints. 

There is a Buca de Beppo in Bally's and also a Tequila Taqueria. We tried the latter, but I wouldn't recommend it. We ate at HEXX bar in Paris, which was located right across the street from the Bellagio and had a great view of the fountain show. Check out Battista's Hole in the Wall right across the street though. That was my favorite restaurant out of all the places I ate during my stay. The Sands Expo Convention Center connected to the Venetian is easily accessible from Bally's especially if you take the short cut that leads you right by the Ferris Wheel. If you don't mind walking, Bally's is close enough to walk to the MGM Grand, New York, Cosmopolitan, Caesar's Palace, and Planet Hollywood. 

I couldn't stream any video on the wifi from the 6th floor so the Internet is kind of weak. Like everything on the strip in Vegas, everything at Bally's is overpriced so expect $3 bottles of soda and $5 bottles of water.
The room service was great, the room decor exceeded my expectations. I like how its on the center of The Strip.

2\/19-23\/2012...... stayed here on comp, Anniversary week........... the only way to stay . Spent a lot of time at the bar in evenings with our favorite bartender "Steve"......... he is a friendly and all around great guy who welcomes you with a great smile and  much talk. 
Loved our room, past and present which viewed the Paris pool and Eiffel tower along with the Fountains of the Belligo. We Loved the sounds of the Fountains and great view. Next time we have to try the Price is right. Great place to stay on comp!!!

Found a bed bug in the shower..rooms are soo blah and dirty and the property is a freaking mess !!! Sooo dirty. It's gross. Covered in pee and sticky stuff... it's awful. I couldn't even stay the stay.

Try penthouse..... spa in your Room is size of little swimming pool... for 20years alwe descent place to stay in Vegas even the building is old....they just finish front Side of Vegas  blvd..look nive

I stayed at Ballys in December. I stayed with a friend on a Friday and Saturday night and had to get a room Sunday night. I'm a total rewards member and went to the check-in desk Sunday morning to try and get a room for that night. They lady told me "They didn't book future rooms there". Although the future room was about six hours in the future. She did make up for it by putting me on the phone with someone that could book the room. They gave the comped room at Ballys, so I was happy. I did have to pay the regular 28 dollar resort fee plus some other four dollar fee. I was perfectly fine with that. In my book, 32 dollars for a room is good.

After I checked in, I went and asked about a shuttle to the airport for the next day. They told me there wasn't one, which I saw. So I booked a Super Shuttle instead. 

Room and everything was find. I just found the customers service a little confusing. Seems like you would want to help people. I'll consider Ballys in the future.

My BF calls me a hotel snob.  Can't blame someone for wanting to stay in a clean hotel room.  Since we knew we'd be in vegas for a wedding and the entire wedding party and guests were staying at Bally's we decided to do the same, for the sake of convenience.  I've never stayed at Bally's before so I had very low expectations.  Come on...I just came from The Hotel and Bellagio...

This is my rating and review:
- 3 stars: Rooms were large, and you can tell they recently remodeled.  It was pretty clean but I didn't get the spacious bathrooms I'm used to having. (NOTE: this room only applies to the new tower.  I don't understand why they'd remodel one tower but not the other)  I guess we got lucky and got the free room upgrade 
- 2 stars:  ceilings are low and smoky, but it's an older casino so this is expected
-4 stars: it's in the middle of the strip so it has easy access to everything you need.  Bellagio and Caesars are just across the way, and cabbing is not necessary so it saves you a ton of money. 

ok, I agree with my bf...I am a hotel snob.

Spent last weekend here and we were upgraded to the celebrity suite for free! The room was at least 1500 square feet, had a gym with a bike machine, master bedroom with whirlpool tub, several couches, a dining table, bar, and an absolutely amazing view. I don't know how I'll ever be able to go back to staying in regular rooms again. I could complain about the lack of $5 tables and douchebag blackjack dealer, but in the grand scheme of things that didn't affect my enjoyment of the hotel at all so I'll let it slide.
I went to go eat at Johnny Rockets around 10pm. The food was delicious, although the line was long service was great and our food didn't take that long to get served.

We had a big room with a king sized bed, non smoking, view of the parking lot. Hotel was centrally located in the strip. We went to a Rod Stewart concert at Caesar's Palace which was close to walk to. My only complaint-paid a resort fee which was to include Wifi. Connection was poor. I wasn't able to get texts, mail, Facebook, Uber. So I paid for mandatory resort fees and didn't use the fitness center or get wifi.
This hotel to me is like a "no frills" type of place.  Rooms are decent sized and clean. Price isn't bad either.

We stayed in the remodeled tower and I have to say I was impressed. I was sceptical going into booking a room here but, once we walked in all my doubts went away. I can't speak for any of the other towers but, the remodeled ones. They have upgraded bedding, televisions, beautiful beds, and really put a lot of thought into the layout of the rooms. I will say this the bed was so comfortable my husband had a hard time getting me out of it that we almost missed our flight. It's also a great location for all the new attractions on the strip as well. Only down fall was the casino....I thought some of the staff was great and others were very detached and almost rude.

Terrible hotel & terrible service!!! Our room (#877) flooded out from the bathroom sink. Woke up to sogging wet carpet by the bed & 1-2 inches of black stinky water\/waterfall overflow from the sink out to the hallway. We called the front desk to tell them, only to have to wait 30 minutes for someone to come up. Then had to go to the check in desk to ask for a new room to get a shower & get all our stuff out from being ruined. The front desk ladies were very rude about any refunds OR help & got us a "manager" he offered to refund our room service charges & the resort fee after I politely asked. A month later I only got the room service credit back & NEVER the resort fee... I emailed them & it took about 4 days for a reply with no help. I also called & they told me to contact my bank. Awesome. So lost $97 due to nasty sewer backup flooding my room & ruining all my stuff. I'll never stay here again.

Received a smoking room even though I 'm allergic to smoke and have asthma and had booked a non smoking room. They were pretty rude about it and said "oh well".  The hotel is not very well ventilated and is very smokey. The room was smelled heavily of smoke too and I was coughing all night. Not a good start to a vacation. The. Next day, I finally got switched. The new room was okay.  Wall paper peeling, and steaks on the wall. They advertise a strip view for deluxe rooms, there is not a strip view, unless you book the ka room in the "tower" they said. Overall just okay.  Service is bad at this hotel.  Decent  price although I will not be staying here again.   I guess I am a true flamingo loyalist :)
Great location on the Strip.  Got my room for $45 per night on Orbitz.  Room was clean and spacious.  No complaints here.

I know they are going to block my one star review via their AUTOMATIC PROGRAM but I still want to complain. This is the worst hotel I've ever stayed in Vegas including motels. I know there is a hidden $33 resort fee for most of hotels in Vegas but what's the meaning of this? Can you believe there is no water in the room. There is no fridge in the room. The room is old and smelly. There is no coffee machine in the room. There is no fan in the bathroom. No window can be opened. Always super long line on the front desk with very inefficient service. Most bad thing is that they only provide you two devices to access their wifi per room for free and it's super slow. Can you believe? Even the cheapest motels provide unlimited wifi now days. Feel free to book a room if you feel all of these are very acceptable.

I absolutely loved my king room. It was very spacious and is suitable for personal and business. 

The host of this hotel was awesome. Bally's has from a hotel to a mall to massages and restaurants. 

Overall I loved everything about this hotel and yes I would be sure to visit again when I come back to Vegas.

SO FREAKING CHEAP. WTF? I didn't think it was possible to find a HOTEL for this price, but it was unbelievably cheap. I was expecting a total shit-hole, but it was actually kinda decent. I shared the room with 5 girls (3 on each bed), not bad at all. However, I could not handle the fact that there was no free wifi. UGH.

The thing is, we were originally supposed to be in the South Tower (which is the older one), but with the $20 trick, we got upgraded to the North Tower. Nice! I can't imagine how bad the South Tower rooms could have been like.

When I came to Vegas last month, I though Ballys was farther up the strip, but no! Its location is great! It's connected to Paris (which was nice when it was raining outside), which is right next to Planet Hollywood, which is right across from Cosmo. Yea.. typing it out makes it seem like a realization of how great the location was haha

A bang for your buck. Just got back from my first vegas trip. When we checked in by a nice staff member we got upgraded to the jubilee tower. Our room was very nice, huge shower, great corner view of the strip. Room was perfect! The first night which was Friday the beach club across the way was pretty loud but after that night it wasn't.  My husband & his best friend LOVED the tacos at the tequila bar during happy hour. $2 tacos, beer, magaritas & tequila shots. We went there every night before bed. Also loved how Ballys was connected to Paris. Gorgeous hotel. I would go back & stay at ballys again without a doubt. The location is perfect.

The only reason Im giving this more than one star is because I stayed in the new tower so the room was nice. 
However, the casino needs to be updated desperately. The downstairs "mall\/food court" was depressing and gross. I only went down there to find the pool. 

The pool was horrible!!!! I didn't even put my towel down, I just got up and left. 

*You can (& should) go to the Paris pool for free since the two hotels are connected. The Paris pool was very nice! Poolside waitresses serving you drinks\/food from 11am-5pm

Some may think this hotel is fine, but it's Vegas. We pay a lot of money for an experience. I won't be making that exchange with Ballys again. There are plenty of awesome hotels in Vegas that are trying harder and succeeding.

I've stayed at many of the Harrah's affiliated hotels in Las Vegas and have had a positive to an outstanding experience in doing so.  But Bally's is seriously crap.  We decided to come on a memorial weekend and were prepared for it to be real busy.  When we arrive and check in I get in a line of only 8 other check ins, it didn't look so bad.  Until we found out there was only 2 employees working to check people in.  A senior citizen training on how to check people in and another senior citizen supervising her. This is ridiculous of all weekends why on have one attendee and in training?  It took an hour to get to the front of the line.  I told them I was surprised why they were so understaffed, they were nice enough to upgrade my room for free.   The next morning I saw a huge line at check in and again just 1 person checking in.  The rest of the stay we were rudely turn away by the valet.  The check out was when I almost lost it.  I was standing in line behind a senior couple who was talking to the employee.  They were having a long conversation about the local sights.  The line behind me is building and they are still talking.  15 minutes go by the attendant and I exchange glances that the seniors are taking too long.  Finally they finish, they are old so I didn't want to rush them.  So when I get tot he counter to check out she tells me "oh I don't work here".  I asked her why she did not inform any of us in the line who have been waiting for close to 20 minutes now.  She just said oh I was busy.  F, her busy yapping it up.   Don't think I will ever stay here again.  I've experience better at Travel Lodge

I don't know why there are so many bad reviews about this place, but I believe this place was really nice. The rooms and bathrooms are good and spacious. The customer service was great. We had a good view of the strip. In addition, the hotel is surrounded by a whole bunch of good bars and food places. I would recommend this place!

Old furnishings and no glamour but plenty comfortable for the price. Service is likewise unspectacular but adequate. Definitely use online check-in to avoid the insane queues.

No bottles of water are provided in the rooms, but they're $1.75 each at one of the gift shops by the food court. To wit: that's much better than $3 from the vending machine on your floor.

Great hotel for location right in the middle-ish of the strip. Rooms are reasonably priced and roomy. If you join the total rewards players club you get an even bigger price cut on the room when you book. I usually stay here when ever i go to Vegas because the staff at the front counter is nice and if you ask for upgrades they try to get them. I got a room upgrade a few weeks ago just for saying it was my b-day. Pool is kinda lame, so we go to another hotels pool. Has cool shopping area with tasty treats on the pool level of the hotel. Some rooms have fridges some don't the bigger ones have more amenities then the regular rooms, but all in all this hotel is a good experience.

Arrived at 1:30 am and had to wait 2 hours in line to check in. At times there was literally 1 person at the front desk checking people in.  Nothing else this hotel could do would make me ever agree to come back.

I went here for the Marine Corps Ball in 2012. When I got to my room, after waiting 45 minutes in line, I noticed a very large urine stain on the floor. The towels were dirty and the bedsheets had human hair all in them. I could've stayed at some desert motel and had a better experience. The casino floor was OK but it was also dirty. Don't waste your time.
Right on the Vegas strip, great place to stay, however no free Wi-Fi is a disappointment.

Really great food and housekeeping staff and room service staff and IT dept. Everything else is "meh"
Only stayed here cause the rooms were free and when we got there at 11 at night after our flight was delayed, the front desk girl told me that even though I reserved a smoking 2 bed room, they gave away all the 2 bed rooms so they were giving me a 1 bed room and a roll away and we could switch rooms the next day. So we still had to be out by check out time the next morning so we could switch rooms and thankfully there was a 2 bedroom ready. Really shitty start for a vacation with all the hassle and attitude they gave us. When I pointed out that I had reserved a 2 bedroom room the chick at the desk told me that reservations are merely a "suggestion".
Blu Pool is okay but definitely a lot of people who aren't appealing to the eye and A LOT of creepy old guys. I'd pay the extra $ to go to Ceasar's pool or a pool party like Wet Republic or Marquee Day Club which is what we did the next 2 days because that first day was pretty bad. Definitely the B-Squad working this pool. They have a DJ playing Top 40 hits and some throwbacks on Friday, Saturday, Sunday. The pool itself was slimy from everyone's lotions and oils. Be careful when walking into the pool as the steps were the most slippery.
The Ichiban Sushi Restaurant next to the pool is AMAZINGLY fresh fish for a decent price- see my separate review for them.
The Bellagio fountains which are across the road are REALLY LOUD and can be hear and seen from most rooms at Ballys\/Paris from 11am to nighttime. Bring binder clips to close the blinds as ours didn't like to stay shut. We had a balcony on our room but the handle was taken off the door because we weren't allowed out. I never understood this- when we stayed at the Cosmopolitan hotel we had a room with a wrap around balcony that we were allowed to hang out on. It was awesome. Old school Vegas hotels really need to catchup to the new places like Aria and Cosmo. 
The resort fee was $15\/day and included internet access for 1 device and gym access. The fee was unavoidable- when I was at Ceasars they comped my fees so....

The stay here has been more than I could've asked for. We stayed at a room overlooking the Eiffel Tower which was great and the interior was clean, chic, and very modern. We had a king-sized bed in the hotel room which was extremely comfortable and the couches by the window was an excellent addition to the room's interior. The casino was conveniently located few steps outside the elevators and everything about this hotel was just great. Would definitely love to stay here again!

The first thing I noticed when I walked into the lobby was the cigarette smoke smell.  Okay, to be fair, all of the hotels\/casinos allow smoking - as annoying as it is.  But I get it.  Gamblers smoke.  However, I walked through most of the casinos on the strip, and none of them had the stench of Bally's.  They all had either some sort of air fresheners to mask the smell, or at the very least better ventilation.  Bally's simply stunk.  And pretty bad.  They definitely need better ventilation in the casino\/lobby.  Secondly, the entire time I was playing the games over three days, NOT ONE cocktail waitress offered me a drink.  I was under the impression that as long as you are gambling, drinks are on the house.  In fact, the one or two waitresses I did see were not accepting anything more than tips for the drinks.  I don't know why I was ignored.  My room was very nice, and extremely big.  I did, however, have to put the heat on 80 degrees to get it warm (I happened to visit Vegas on the coldest days of the year).  The hotel\/casino was nice, but comparatively speaking, not nearly as nice as the others I saw on the strip, for similar prices.  Next time I go to Vegas I'm staying elsewhere.

We have stayed at Bally's for MANY (20+) years.  Our last visit in July makes me rethink going back to Ballys.  First of all the NOISE from the DRAIS nightclub on the roof of the Cromwell is so darn loud until 2:00 am or later, you can't sleep.  NEVER have I experienced such disruption at Ballys.  Room service for some reason is not available in the evening any more -- seems they got rid of the Sidewalk Cafe and replaced it with something else.  I don't typically use room service, but I always check out the menu just in case...well, this was a just in case moment as we were not feeling well and could not go out for dinner as planned.  Luckily I brought some protein bars since we couldn't get room service.  What hotel on the strip does not have evening room service?  Not feeling well, noise level beyond acceptable...I think we are probably reconsidering Ballys after so many years.

We got a decent rate for a one night stay. Booked for a double queen bed and the room was spacious. 

When we arrived late at the counter there was a long line. Service was slow. Only three people were working on a busy night. So it took awhile to checkin, but the front desk chick was friendly. 

Our stay on the side of the 8th floor we had a view: the "Linq" strip mall sign, liquor store, the monorail tracks was close so we see it pass by every 30 minutes, Cromwell hotel, the Flamingo hotel and some lights from "The Strip". 

The comfort level was good because of how spacious our room was. The bath was decent and clean. Our room was non-smoking and didn't stink. The queen bed we slept in was just okay. 

The kinks:

- Hole on the bed sheet 
- Room AC sounded like a bathroom fan
- Electrical outlets are out of place 

We were told that the newer rooms are on the front of the hotel. Before my stay here I always wondered the theme of this hotel. Is Bally's a Tomorrow-land theme? The monorail that stops by and the round arches at the front hotel entrance makes it seem like it just a tiny bit? Anyways, it's now part of my list of collection of Vegas on the strip hotel stays. 

Being one of the oldest hotels on strip may not be your typical "Bally's Total Fitness" but if it fits within a budget for a quick stay, it's recommended.

I just checked out of this property and i am very disappointed on how a host named Taylor handled my situation! I talked to her a night before my check out to see if there's anything she can do with my charges and she did took care of some of it and i thought that was okay. Then i asked her what my total will be when i check out? Then she told me $65. So the next morning i was about to check out, the front desk told me i owed certain amount I wasn't expecting! Then i went and talk to "Taylor" again and she looked at my charges and told me "oh, you charged food to your room"! Then i told her, i had that charged on Thursday and i talked to you on Friday. She then said,"oh I must've added it wrong". Really?! Well, next time make sure you added everything correctly because it's very inconvenient to have to take care of everything again! The whole reason for me talking to a host so I won't have any problem when i check out! If i knew that was the case, I should've stayed somewhere else and given my money to other properties instead of this place! I will not stay at Ballys again!!!

No. Just no. We stayed here NYE 2013 on a very last minute trip, it was the ONLY hotel with a room left...I hated it, the bed sucked, the customer service sucked..I swore I'd never stay there again! 

Fast forward to Labor Day weekend 2015, my "dirty 30"...we went to Vegas to celebrate with a group of people. We were the last ones to book our room, and ended up booking here so we would be at the same hotel as the rest of our party. Wow, that was a huge mistake. Every single person that works at Bally's must HATE their job and takes it out on the guests. I've never been to a hotel in Vegas with a more unhappy bunch of front desks agents, card dealers, bar tenders. The nicest person was the maid! Oh, and the parking is a big effing joke. My husband tore his Achilles' tendon and was just starting to walk again at the time of this trip. We tried to valet, but it was full throughout the entire weekend, so we had to self park our vehicle in BFE at the Paris, and then walk through the entire Paris hotel before finally arriving at our lovely motel. Yeah, yeah, I shoulda just dropped him off at the front with the bags and not made him walk--we had no idea we would be forced to park a mile away. (First world problems, I know.... there are starving children in Africa that's way more important than this.) 

I can assure you that we will never stay at Bally's again.
This place is neither good or bad. Just meh. The facilities are clean and it is rather dated....the best part about ballys is its excellent location in the heart of the strip!
Great rooms for the price.  Gambling is a lot of fun and the payouts are better than most of the strip.  Location can't be beat as well.

One star...I feel like Jon and Vince as they walk into the casino in "Swingers".  
Bally's is "old" school.  The patrons are farting dust they're so old.  Appropriately, the food in this joint tastes like a retirement home.  Salt please! 
One star b\/c this place still attempts to feign luxury.  This is luxury in the same way an 89 Buick is luxury.

Bally's, you've lost a customer for life! 

Fellow Yelpers, if your time is worth any amount of money, avoid staying at Bally's at any cost since you will be held captive in their check in line for about an hour. I came during a Wed night but I can only imagine the frustration during a weekend... (There is also a line for Diamond and Platinum members but even that line was 7 people deep with 1 check in agent). In addition, if your reservation was made on the same day you won't be able to use their mobile online checkin. This is 2016, not 1999... get with it Bally's!

In any case, obviously the hotel doesn't have their best interest at heart. The faster they check people in, the faster they will be on the casino floor, eating in the restaurants or spending money in a variety of other ways rather than waiting in line for check-in. If you are considering Bally's due to the low price, I'd highly suggest Paris instead since they have a row of automated check in kiosks so you are in and out and are able to enjoy your time in Vegas starting on right note.

Oh and also, the renovation in the front of the property makes you feel as if you are walking through a flea market every time you want to return from the strip...

Located pretty centrally on the Strip!

Early check in @ 10a: $22 fee
Early check in @ 12p: Free if you are a Total Rewards member (free membership)
Check in @ 4p

Con: Resort fees
Pro: Free wifi but Con: only 2 devices allowed

Our room was on the side of the hotel & had a gorgeous view of The Linq!  If you can, definitely ask for that view!  The elevators were janky!  The first elevator we were on stopped & everyone got out in fear that we would get stuck.  The room was nice!  King size bed, very comfortable. The pillows were horrible though & you have to constantly flip sides because it would instantly go flat once you laid your head into it.  Spacious & plenty of mirrors for when getting ready to go out.

Okay, so any of you that are like me, and take a lot of these negative Yelp reviews with a grain of salt, because you know a lot of people just complain. Rest assured, Ballys will not disappoint. I do recommend upgrading to the newer Tower which I believe is the Jubilee. Sure, maybe my experience would have been different if I was in the older Tower, but the bottom line is Bally's did not disappoint. Yes it is one of the older casinos on the strip. However the room was great(Comfortable bed, fridge included), the view is amazing, and the service was awesome.

Trip overview:

I came with my wife, my brother, and his wife. My brother had booked the Jubilee Tower, we had actually booked the older Tower because it was a little bit cheaper. When my brother checked in he simply asked if there were any free upgrades so we could all be together and sure enough they booked me into the Jubilee tower right across from his room at no additional charge. 

Also, you must sign up for the Total Rewards program. The benefits are great. This was my first time using the total rewards program and already just a few days later I already have comped rooms available. Sure you pay the resort fee, but that's a lot less than you would pay otherwise.

Lastly, Ballys truly is in a great spot, it does not take long to walk down to the Mirage, or up to Planet Hollywood, and has easy connected access to Paris.

The view from my brother's room could see the Eiffel Tower, as well as the fountain show at the Bellagio, which was a great at night. The view from my room was also nice, which included the new linq attraction, and also looked especially cool at night.

We all had a blast! I look forward to coming back soon.

We enjoyed so much our stay, close to everywhere. The room was extremely clean, nice, comfortable bed, and worth the money we spent.
The staff was friendly, and helpful. The facilities were great, and spotless as well. Even the breakfast was delicious.
For sure, we'll come back and highly recommend to anyone to stay here !

Nice big room!! kinda a crappy view of the ph tower.. We could kinda see the pool ... no strip... but whatever! we were up on the 21st floor .. did I say huge room! cause it was! and we had the cheapest package available through an allegiant air package. I would definitely recommend this place to anyone, and will certainly stay again!

We've stayed here a few times now.  I wrote an extensive review about the gym, but I wanted to give an update for our most recent stay during this past xmas weekend.

The good things are the location and free, accessible parking.  Right in the middle of everything, although if you want to go to Luxor and Excalibur it's a little far.  But it's connected to Paris, which I like because we usually go to Vegas when it's really hot or really cold.  So you can stay indoors for a little extra.  It's also relatively close to Planet Hollywood, which has a lot of my favorite spots.

The biggest issue was the ridiculous check in time.  We were in line for at least 40 minutes.  Think about that.  You just finished a long drive or flight with all of your bags and you have to stand in line for that long just to check in.  That wait was bad enough that I would consider at least trying another hotel out of fear that the check-in at Bally's would be the same.

On top of that, we were given the rooms furthest from the elevator.  Well, technically there was one room further than ours, but at that point what difference does it make.  It would have been nice to get a more convenient room after the long check-in, but those two things combined make me hesitant to stay at Bally's again.

We stayed here for my birthday. We had a smoking king bed room. Hard finding rooms that let you smoke in them. So I was glad that Ballys had one. Our room was a nice size. Big bead. Nice tv and a sitting area . The bed was pretty comfortable. I would stay here again.

I came to Las Vegas with my husband who is attending a conference. I came specifically to get some sun as I live in a very rainy location. There's a huge sign in front of the pool that says pool closed for the season. Really? What the hell does that mean? It's 70° outside idiots. So freaking angry right now. Oh also? The rooms are gross and the carpet is 90 years old and moldy. Stay somewhere else. Plus the restaurants in here r disgusting. Addendum: don't hold your conferences here either. They treat you like a criminal. They ask for your ID for with every single purchase even a one dollar coffee. I'm not even kidding.

Room was nice. Went to Vegas for my son's wedding and spent a week at Bally's. Got great rates. It took forever to get our room, so this is something they need to work on. The casino was smokey and the restaurants in the hotel area were expensive. So, forced to go outside on the strip to spend money. Otherwise, Bally's was ok, pool was closed, not much entertainment and do you think you can keep the people from being so pushy on the "free" comps.?

Decided to try our hand at a PETSTAY room! We usually stay downtown so this time around, it was a somewhat new experience for us all. For a Strip hotel, Bally's is a good option if you are on a budget and want to experience all of the blinky lights. The hotel seems to be undergoing some cosmetic work so the entrance to self\/valet parking is very easy to miss. Check-in line can be long...be prepared! PETSTAY rooms are regular rooms that allow dogs (2 dogs maximum, under 50 pounds). "Dog relief area" was a bit of a trek down the elevators, through retail area then outside...small astroturf triangle. Was nice that we ran into other dog owners who brought their dogs. Hotel itself seems a bit dated but was OK for us. May stay again when the time is right!

I was not very thrilled with the rooms this place had to offer.  Our first room had a leaky tub, so we called the front desk and they sent up a plumber.  When we came back later the tub was still leaking, so went down to the front desk who told us we were put in for a new room.  I'm glad we went down to the front desk because otherwise we would never have known this.  Our second room smelled like someone had just smoked weed, so we called down and she granted us a third room.  She first tried to see if the housekeeper could just go in and  spray the room.  We politely declined that offer as we didnt want to sit in a room tht smelled like weed and floral spray.  Well, the third room had a sink that didn't quite work, but by this time we were done moving rooms so we didn't even bother telling them.  The minute you walk in the casino it wreaks like cigarette smoke. Some other hotels are better able to control it.  I feel as thought cig smoke is something you can't get away from in Vegas.  I will say that for most part the front desk was very helpful with the room situation.  The first girl I spoke to the night we checked in seemed a little annoyed I called, but all the others were very sweet. If it wasn't for the room situation I probably would have given higher stars.  The room altogether looked outdated, old, and not really that clean. On the  bright side the hotel has a good breakfast buffet and cafeteria area in the basement.  It is also convenient and in the middle of the strip and on the monorail.  Maybe we just had bad luck with rooms\/plumbing.

It was alright for the price we paid during a major holiday weekend...all except for the vomit stains on the hall carpets...and hooray for not getting any scabies...that I know of. Plus when you walk into the lobby, it smells like chlorine.

Worst part of my Bally's experience was check in.  The que took an hour to get through on a Sunday night.  I arrived at 8:40 pm. It did not look like it would be too long, after all there were 6 workers there.  Unfortunately, 2 were exclusively for the priority guests (there was no line for them, and usually no guest either so they must've been attending to other things, because they helped very few customers.  Every other employee at check in was for us average folk.  Four windows said "available", but only 2 were handling the line, and very slowly at that.  The other 4 workers I have no idea what they were doing, certainly not helping to check people in or interacting with anyone.

Frankly, it made me feel bent out of shape after a very bumpy and stressful flight, rude airport information providers and gossiping co-workers at the Shuttle booths who didn't want to help me figure out the shuttle situation so they directed me to the booth next to them, which was closed because those ladies were hanging out in that first booth. Followed by an unattentive shuttle driver who left me standing in front of his locked van for 15 minutes in 108 degree heat at night.  I am a woman, travelling alone and in a foreign city... it was getting to be too much. It's okay, call me weak, but I was so ready to cry or scream at someone.  (I didn't though, so way to go, girl!)  I wasn't off to a great start in Vegas, but that was not the hotel's fault.  I simply wished the desk staff could have been considerate enough to flip their signs from Available to Closed being that they really were not available at all.  

Now, things get better, Thank Goodness!  Once I got to the counter everything went quickly for me.  The lady was friendly and efficient.  I had reserved a king sized bed yet was told I was booked into a 2  queen sized bedroom.  I asked her if she could find me one, she did, in the Indigo Tower, "except, " she said, "it is on the 6th floor."  I did not understand why this was important. It was my first time in Vegas and I was annoyed and tired and just wanted to drop my bags in my room, use the toilet and find something to eat!  I told her, rather grumply, that I didn't care what floor it was on.  So she sent me to the 6th floor.  

It's a strange layout, this hotel, lots of winding corridors with mirrors on the walls (so you are looking into infinity).  But I liked the feel of it.  I am not a big hotel amenity user, though this is Vegas and I was there to see the sights, lights, people and toss a few pennies at the slots.  So to me what would be important would be the bedroom because it would be where I would catch some downtime, sleep, eat.

The room was very large and I liked how it was set up.  The art could have been better certainly, but then some drunk might decide to steal it so best to keep it kinda 3rd Class ugly.  The bathroom was very clean and well stocked. There were multiple light settings so it could be very bright or at night when I soaked I could dim it to a more relaxing state.  Downside:  water tasted soapy\/chemically and was always too hot.

The closet was big enough for two people and held a safe within it.  What the room was missing was a small fridge, a microwave or coffeepot.  I brought a lot of my own food with me to save money and have more to play with,  Thankfully none of it needed to be refrigerated, but it was inconvenient to have to walk through the labyrinth of the 6th floor to get to a Soda or snack machine & the ice machine (not that I'd want an ice machine in my room!)  The floor was extremely quiet.  In fact, it was so quiet that sometimes when I needed a break from the CHAOS that is Las Vegas I would get a book from my room and take it to the sitting area on the floor (it was roomier, less cluttered and warmer).

The bed was wonderfully perfect.  We both loved it, very comfy and the pillows were great too.  Very clean.  There was no real blanket on the bed, maybe something that resembled a throw.  Whatever it was, it wasn't enough.  I have no idea why we never asked housekeeping for an extra one.  Perhaps it was just too convenient of an excuse for spooning.  

Room's downside:  The thermostat could not seem to cooperate with our desires. It was pretty much always freezing in there, until it wasn't.  The fan would blow all night, right across the bed.  You could actually feel the breeze & without a real blanket it was sometimes difficult to sleep (5 days\/4 nights).  And yes, I did come to discover the mystery as to why the 6th floor was undesirable... no view.  Yep, that's right, our room looked over a roof with giant ventilation fans and blue lights that shown straight into the windows at night if we had not closed the heavy drapes.

Negatives: Slow check-in, thermostat broken, oh and wi-fi... it only worked about 20 min the entire trip. And the guy who was sent to repair it was rude, said I should invest in a real computer.  Like, I'd travel with a desk top computer!

Great location and we enjoyed the fact that it's also a stop on the monorail. Appreciated the check-in\/check-out kiosk but didn't know there was a $28 fee to use it till we saw our bill at check-out. There weren't any signs or notifications of this fee before use. 
The last day we were here there wasn't any hot water. Overall the staff was nice and place was pleasant and clean.

I'm a hotel snob. Fine, I admit it! But my friend Jalena had a budget that I had to stick with, so I obliged. I would never recommend anyone staying in the Ballys, unless in the future they did deep cleaning, update the sheets, curtains, mattress, pillows...basically they need to renovate or move the hotel to the South end of the strip in the vacant spot next to Circus Circus! 

Upon the first night we arrived, out heat was broke! It was December....how is the heat in the hotel room broke? So just like out of some funny comedy starring Jack Black, the maintenance man arrives in a gray suit, greasy and chubby. I almost couldn't contain my laughter. 

Other crazy unmentionables....I'm a fanatic about clean sheets and to my amazement, there were no duvets, not top blankets...nada. The sheets served as your top cover. Umm...but its winter, its 50 degrees outside, and no blanket! I also got a chance to peek at the mattress. It was yellow, dingy, and raggedy...it literally belonged in the dumpster. 

Talk about getting what you pay for....in my opinion, I still paid too much for that!

Nice place. I love it that it is connected to Paris and there is a small food court on the lower levet. The rooms look lovely, new furniture, nice granite bathroom, the only that was old was the safe and the TV.  The pool area is really small and the music is really loud for the area size. 

The casino was fun, wish they had more Pai Gow tables.

Stayed here for a work convention that was hosted at the attached Paris casino.  My idea was that the convention hall at Paris was mere feet away from this joint.  Convenience.  I could have stayed at Vdara for only a few bucks more.  Huge mistake.  Greasy face prints from kids all over the windows.  Everything is beat to hell and outdated.  This is, by far, the smokiest casino I've ever been to.  Morning, noon, and night.  And I've been to dozens of casino\/resorts in trips to Vegas over the years.  Super low class.  Time to tear this place down and build a new spot.  The Thai restaurant had good tasting food but ridiculously overpriced and blew me out.  Mattresses were super cheap and uncomfortable.  $5 for a brewed coffee and you have to go all the way to the other end of the casino in the morning.  Do not stay here for any reason.  There are way better places in Vegas for the same or less money.  Stay at Rio, Harrah's, Hard Rock, MGM, or Vdara\/Aria when they are on sale.

Going to this hotel was totally worth it!!! We got a great package deal with great rates and I'm happy I went here with my husband.  Bally's is connected to Paris hotel ( where we went to eat many times).  Paris Hotel is located across the street from Bellagio and Ceaser's palace.  The location was ideal and once again the rates were totally worth it.  Our hotel had a balcony and it was very relaxing.  The room was huge and there was tons of space.  There was a desk, couch, tv and bed.  There is no fridge but the location makes up for this.  The pool was sweet and had a tiki bar, you could see the monorail pass by.  The only complaint is that it takes long to get to the pool and you have to take an elevator and walk through the stores in the basement area. I would go here again.

This is not the first time we've stayed at Bally's.  I love Bally's for the following reasons:

1. Location.  Bally's is pretty much center strip.  It is attached to Paris, just down from Planet Hollywood, and across the street from Ceasar's, Bellagio, Cosmopolitan, and City Center. 
2. Total Rewards property.  Bally's, Ceasar's, Harrah's, Rio, Flamingo, Planet Hollywood, and Imperial Palace are all owned by the same company and on the same rewards system.  So you can get points for gambling at any of those casinos and sometimes this gets you free rooms. :) 
3. Free shuttle to Rio. No taxi fare!
4.  Nice rooms, good gambling, low drama. 

Suggestions for improvement: 
Could we get a fridge in the room please? And maybe a coffee maker? Then you'd be 5 stars in my book.

Worst experience ever! Bally's sucks! Never have I been told that we cannot bet because we lost. They literally said that we could not complain because we are Asian! Talk about the most RACIST COMPANY on earth! Even the "black" guy next to me said that this was the most RACIST thing he's ever experienced!!! All Asian 's stay away because while they will placate to you that will treat you as 3rd class citizen. Evan all my friends  that experienced this said that this b was unacceptable!  DO NOT ACCEPT THEIR RACISM!!!

Spent a weekend here earlier this month. Can't comment on the prices since my rooms were comped. Diamond check-in was quick. I was in n' out in 5min tops. I had a room in the newly renovated tower. North tower I believe? Suffice to say, I was pretty surprised how nice the room looked. Before walking into my room, I hadn't realized it was newly remodeled in October. Shared the room with a couple friends. I know one friend made use of the alarm clock\/radio ipod docking station.
The casino portion. The times I've played here it's been good. Staff are friendly, courteous. Selection of games & dining spots are decent.
The weekend overall went without a hitch. The rooms aren't as big as what I'm used to at the Rio. But they definitely were nice. Would stay here again if I chose somewhere on the strip.

I will never stay at Bally's again. We were given a room that when you entered you were completely overwhelmed by cleaners...I love a good, clean smell, but if I take a deep breath and sneeze because there is THAT MUCH cleanser in the air, that's ridiculous - but I wouldn't even complain if that was all. The bed was a hazard. The bottom actually stuck out three inches from the box spring...it was only a matter of time before we injured ourselves (I mean, seriously, we are in Vegas so coming back to the room drunk is normal). My husband only skinned his ankle on it...lucky us. NO I AM NOT FINISHED. Then, the last straw...there was no hot water. I called to report it, and she asked if I put 'all the faucets in the room on hot'. Um, well no, let me try that BS...in a friggin' hotel!! So after (I kid you not!!!!) 20 minutes, yes, there was hot water. You literally had to run EVERY FAUCET IN THE ROOM ON HOT FOR 20 MINUTES TO GET HOT WATER!! What the heck, Bally's? Don't make the same mistake I did, enjoy your Vegas trip...and don't stay here!

This place seems dated because it is even with it's modification.  Shame.  Great great location.  On the corner where it's close to Bellagio, Flamingo and Caesars.  Next door to Paris.  The rooms are huge and clean, but boring.  Having said all that, why the low rating.  Pathetically small and boring casino.  Even with it's location, it still is far from everything.  Why?  Because they built the hotel and casino away from the strip.  So to cross the street, you have to walk a really far distance to the corner.  No shopping.  No restaurants or good ones.  No nothing.  It's is just a shame.

We stayed here 4\/9 to 4\/13 of 2015.
Old and shabby with chipped paint in the halls, and worn carpeting.  The popcorn ceiling in our room was peeling.  Check in was a long pain.  Check out was worse.  They charged us for an upgrade and we didn't get one.  The smart aleck lady said "This is why you should check out the night before."  Then she started bad mouthing the guy that checked us in.  All of this as we waited while time evaporated to get to the airport.

The rooms were big.  The gym SUCKS.  It is small and the equipment is old.  We did have a lot of fun at the pool, though.  It is nice to walk over to Paris and wish you had stayed there.

One bright note is that the Indigo lounge was a lot of fun with the band that played Journey, Guns n Roses, etc.
For how old school it is it's not a bad place if you wanna come and play for cheap. They have low limits.

This hotel was so bland, I cannot even recall what my room looked like.  The slots were abundant.  I do not even recall eating there. They do have a nice waiting area for the airport shuttle.  But other than that, it was not all that impressive or exciting.  Now, at night, they did have a nice free show with a dynamic R&B band.  I was able to view the full show from my slot machine.

The Bally's of today represents a Las Vegas of yesterday: A name for all to know, a location desired more than most, a mid level property for the people. Heydey no longer, more and more properties both new and renovated are creeping past Bally's as the decades roll along. Even then, Bally's remains a solid choice for the ever changing face of The Strip.

As a part of the Caesars Entertainment family, Bally's is a part of the largest gaming corporation in the world. Total Rewards lovers can earn and spend their points here where the comps are easier to utilize than higher end properties. The casino itself is rather average by today's standards with a solid array of slot machines and just under 100 tables. I'm pleased to report Spanish 21 is available here and a beefed up a poker room is available for hold 'em lovers.

The resort itself is as massive as it looks. Home to nearly 3,000 rooms, there is a good shot that there will be rooms here than a lot of the smaller places that sell out quickly. While the room rates will always fluctuate, the retail side of the hotel is reasonable for Vegas standards, especially when considering the middle of the Strip location.

Hotel dwellers take note: If you're going to be situated in the North Tower, be prepared for Las Vegas circa 1995 rooms. If at all possible, try to get a Jubilee room, the equivalent of the GO series at the Flamingo. It's contemporary, modern, and a true surprise for Bally's visitors. Concierge is on point as always, a huge plus considering the grade of the resort.

The best part of Bally's is also the most surprising: Major upgrades on the food front. Once considered the boring laughing stock of the local culinary scene, Bally's is now boasting one of the better steakhouses in the mid strip in Bally's Steakhouse (http:\/\/www.yelp.com\/biz\/ballys-steakhouse-las-vegas). Adding to the meat is their renovated buffet, the classic Sterling Brunch (http:\/\/www.yelp.com\/biz\/sterling-brunch-las-vegas) which has upgraded furiously not just in price ($40+ per person) but in the abundance of luxurious choices (especially on the sea food front) as well. BLT is set to come in sometime in the next few months and other quick bite businesses (::coughs:: chains!) will likely surface their lots come 2014.

What's next for Bally's? Who knows. A face lift is most likely given the overhaul of Caesars property renovations but something tells me it'll all start from the inside out first. Be sure to enjoy Bally's before another classic Las Vegas property joins the present.

This time we decided to try another hotel. Plus we didn't really want to drive from
Hotel to the Planet Hollywood like we did last time. 

Ballys located in the middle of the strip. The only inconvenient was there was no U-turn around the strip area. 

Check-in was pretty fast eventhough there was a long line. Check out was just as fast, just call the number or turn on the tv and choose the checkout menu and you good to go. 

The room was pretty big compare to the last hotel we stayed at. It was pretty nice and the AC did a good job for the outside heat. 
No fridge but you can just bring your cooler into your room like we did. 

There's iron, safety box & hair dryer. Everything is clean and very nice. We might stay here again next time. The only crazy from this hotel is just the location for the traffic, well can't help because it's the strip!

Came by for a two night stay over the weekend. Despite being an older, less-well known property, the experience was okay.

The lobby area was well ventilated (i.e. no cigarette smoke, unless you're standing next to someone who's smoking) and the staff is friendly.

Unlike the Flamingo, the elevator setup was staggered so that floors 16-26 are on a separate set of elevators than floors 1-16.

Did the $20 trick, and we got upgraded to the Diamond Floor with a larger room and 2 beds.

Who really cares about anything else when you have a comfy bed and the world's best night light!? 

Will the elevator stop on the 23rd floor?! Punch the "down" button. Light it up!

Are you feeling lucky? Wait. Wait. Wait for it.  What-the-hell-avator? 

Push the "up" button & BING! "going up!"  Up to the top floor we ride.  

Then down we go....to the 23rd floor! Apparently, the only way to get down from the 23rd floor is via up. But not always. That's Vegas, baby. 

So, the elevator was a joke, but worse was the staff's reaction. I will hand it to everyone from "the suit" in the elevator (we reported it to him directly in real-time and he questioned our credibility.) Hilarious. Absolutely not confident in him, we stopped at the (not terribly) friendly faces behind the front desk...everyone seemed consistently not too concerned about this elevator situation. 

They do respond more swiftly when your room has no heat though. That was the first night's entertainment. The heater repair guy made it quickly up though and even gave a nice play by play as to the problem. And just for your own laugh - I now understand the sensory effect of both cold and warm BO. I bet they run this guy ragged. 

This is sounding pretty two-star-ish, isn't it!? But no...

HIGH ROLLER all night long. I'd ridden the high roller my previous trip to Vegas and that was a "once and done" experience for me. Eh. 

I was over the High Roller but it wasn't done with me! Little did I realize upon checking in to Bally's that I'd be soon staring that baby in the eye from the 23rd floor. "How do you like me now?" that amazing wheel wanted to know. I was challenged but still undecided. 

Go out to eat and return...WOW!! Beautiful! Softly turning and the lights! And so, the High Roller lit my night. World's Best. It won me over. 

For the price (I think it was like $180 on a premium night, short notice - Expedia) and the view\/location and the comfy bed...I had fun with the elevator situation, loved the roller, and all-around would stay here again if dictated by necessity. Note: this was late Nov. 2014)

I'm actually surprised this hotel is still here.  I haven't been here since I was a little kid, but we decided to venture in on our last trip.  After all the hoopla of entering the hotel, you'll find a really small casino.  It was just funny after taking all the escalators and moving platforms that we entered this tiny casino.  I'll probably skip this hotel on my next walk down the strip.

Ballys has nice rooms and a decent casino aesthetic (though a little out-dated) The casino is also host to the show, Jubilee which is great, albeit way-to-topless. It connects to Paris hotel\/casino by a hallway of shoppes and is owned by the same man.

The Valet is slow and often full but the self-park is a viable option for providers in a rush. 

There is no security at the towers. Oh, another great thing is that many of the rooms have Bidées(sp?) making it great for people who are there to engage in consensual greek fun.

Location wise, this is great. Centrally located on the strip, it's a brief walk to pretty much every major casino. Best price for that location as well. Appreciated the wifi included in the resort fee. Was able to connect 2 devices daily. Hotel wasn't noisy in our room, spare the outside noise - which was pretty crazy. Room was clean, water pressure in the shower was phenomenal! A couple of lights were out in the room, and the fan didn't work in the bathroom. Wasn't a big enough issue to make a fuss about it though. No major complaints, but definitely not a luxury hotel if you're staying in an average room. Even gave the desk agent $20, and was told we were getting a room looking at Caesars and the strip....yeah, no, we were facing the Linq and the giant Ferris wheel. *side eye*

Terrible guest service. Had to wait 20 minutes to speak with Fabian the guest services manager on the phone who informed me because it was after 1 PM on a week day the only way to get a corkscrew would be to purchase one somewhere else. Save your money and go somewhere they might care you're staying there.

What's so great about staying at Bally's??  It's the center of the Strip at a reasonable rate and best of all no cab lines!!  Say what??!  There are two towers, one facing Flamingo and the other the Strip.  Yes, the rooms are a bit outdated by a few years, but it's still completely functional.  The rooms and hallways are clean so it does what it's supposed to do when you're in Vegas.  Gives you a room to sleep in.

beyond cheesy...
Only reason bunked here for new years 2014 is got comped off father-in-laws' degenerate slot play on my total rewards card.
Only good thing is that you can hop over to MGM or paris intra-hotel. Really a souped up ghetto casino and pad. Havent stayed here since 1998, and even though they remodeled rooms, mine had stained walls, very dusty, dust filled room, terrible beds and linens, and the cheapest towels this side of wal-mart. I have NEVER felt a cheaper towel it was almost like bathroom sandpaper awful. Room reeked of smoke at nights as halls were laid waste to by smokers, as cancer crept underneath our front door. Not even a minibar or fridge in the room. Were talking cookie-cutter, no frills shit.  And great color choices there team management, off-orange tones... PUKE. Room had a safe with big chipped paint spot and the inside was gross, like a lint filled dryer filter as the base. Felt like your putting your valuables on top of a dead animal or road kill.
Casino? Besides being easily navigational (because its small and straight), table games are the utmost joke...they literally had ONE or TWO single\/double deck tables COMBINED, maybe 5-6 total blackjack tables in the ENTIRE casino. All the rest bullshit mississippi stud\/texas hold em poker those stupid retard-fuck games.
Even their casino cage sucks...max 2 open sometimes wait 5-10 minutes just to cash in your shitty ass leftovers from the wack-ass selection of games you were forced to play.
On top of it all, the main entrance (escalator through those cool blue rings at night) completely shut down, construction all around it. 
The only thing I liked here was the sportsbook which is sweet, and...thats about it. Also best property to get to the las vegas pinball hall of fame, which me and my son love each time to visit. I dont think they even have a cafe anymore, pretty pathetic vegas strip joint.
Must say, Larry at check in is a cool dude though. (black middle aged with glasses)
Machines are a dismal joke good luck I had none.
And needless to say, not even close to an upscale clientele or vegas property. If ghetto-slumming is your idea of a good vegas stay, a good choice. And their jubilee show that I saw a few years back has some ugly-ass 40+ bitchez running crazy with naked titties. Please change them and your rooms again.
Good luck on those bullshit blazing 7 machines.

Our room had chunks of gross hair on the shower wall. I called to complain and asked for an upgrade but they said none were available. A Supervisor came up to remove it. The next day they cleaned our room and with my asthma with the STRONG cleaning products I had to get out for hours because I couldn't breathe,  and again they didn't have upgrades to move us. I called the next day, and they FINALLY had an upgrade available  (3rd day)! The upgrade wasn't any better ... the women's restroom door didn't unlock, and the cold water faucet didn't open...after attempting several times, I hurt my wrist..I gave up. It's too bad, I went for my birthday and had this bad experience.  P.s. sheets were also stained on one corner.

Terrible check in process with over 50 people waiting to check in and only 4 service personnel. After 60 mins, we are about half way through the line. You can do the math to figure how long the wait is.

Ballys is a great deal because of location, location, location. 
I give it three stars for ambiance and first impressions. We stayed at the South Tower and the decor\/room condition was straight out of the 1980s Love Boat era of interior decor. Casino floor was aight. Walls couldn't muffle out the giggling of drunken college girls stumbling down the hallway. 

So how does it get four stars? For shopaholics and big ballers, its nestled across from the Bellagio and Caesars. Can we say cha-ching for Chanel, Prada, Louis Vuitton, Hermes, etc.?
For hammy tourists, its right next to Paris (Hello Eiffel Tower! Oui, oui to the Arc de Triomphe!). For movie-lovers, its an easy walk to watch the Bellagio's spectacular water show, ala Ocean's 11. And for old people, it's an easy shuffle to each of these destinations when you're traveling with your mom and aunties. Good deal.

I was actually pleasantly surprised with my stay ay Bally's over President's Day weekend.  I had booked a room in the North Tower for two nights for a little under $100 including taxes, which was a pretty good deal.  Upon check-in, my boyfriend pulled the $20 trick at check-in and was able to get us upgraded to a room in the Diamond Level...sweet!  The room was very clean and spacious and there was even an extra sink outside the bathroom, which was nice.

Now I know Bally's is not the newest or chicest hotel out there but there are some great things about it.  First of all, it is located in the middle of the Vegas Strip and is connected to Paris...awesome!  Although older than a lot of casinos on the Strip, it is still in very good condition and very clean compared to some other places.  Plus, their slot machines loved me when I stayed over the weekend and I was able to win over $300 playing penny slots...woohoo!  I would definitely stay here again on a budget again and hopefully win me some more money ;)

I am giving one star because I could not give zero star.  I have been over the world and stayed in many different hotels in my past.  My experience with this hotel's host and customer service is just horrible.  Basically I spent 2 hours and talked to 8 different people tonight and still not able to get my room reservation issue resolved.  Out of the eight people I talked to, 3 people pretended they could not hear me and hung up.  3 people were not helpful and told me to call back.  One conversation was cut off in the middle of the conversation.   But above all,  Yoon Kim, who is Asian market host tops it all.  She had a very bad attitude with no professionalism in hotel customer services at all.   She showed nothing but rude and mean spirit.  We had our reservation for three rooms and one of the rooms was promised to be a comp room.  When we tried to change our reservation from 4 days to 3 days, Yoon Kim said she can not honor what the hotels has promised for the first comp room because of the host we worked with was fired from Bally.  We expressed that we believe that a reputable company should honor their promise and it has nothing to do with their employee got fired!   Beyond my comprehension, I can not believe that a hotel employee would yell at their guests?  Did this hotel ever provide hospitality training to their employees?   I will be documenting my experience and  filing a formal compliant to this hotel chain's corporate office.   

Note:   person I talked to tonight:  Yoon Kim, Bryan, Cindy, Rick, Tina, Felix, 2 other hosts who were on cellphone line with bad receptions and hung up on me.  And per Rick, they can not provide their last names to the clients, am I hearing this right?

All my friends have raved about staying here as it is in prime location and for the cheap factor. It is in a great location, central to the North and South strip, and I visited the casino as I had a match play given by Total Rewards. Dealer was funny and helpful to those who were new to Blackjack. Lost my $, but not as quickly as I have at other casinos. Great sized casino as well, but cocktail waitresses are always in a jiffy. Could not even get one to give me a drink, and the lady next to me did not even have a chance to tip her.

For the price the location of this hotel is awesome and is probably worthy of 4 stars but there were a few, let's say oddities, that knock it back to 3. 

The check in experience was pretty bad. We arrived on a Friday afternoon, peak time for check in at a hotel on the strip on any given Friday but this was Nascar weekend so it was even busier than normal. They only had 3 windows open for check in, 3. Oh excuse me, there was a 4th but that was exclusively for platinum members so we mere peasants weren't even allowed to glance in the direction of that window. So we wait patiently for our turn, which took forever because it seems every group that went to check in had some special request or another. Then there were the two chicks who didn't seem to understand what a line was, who kept pacing back and forth in front of the check in windows waiting to make eye contact with one of the check in clerks to ask whatever their ridiculous question was. No one took the bait and they ended up wandering off eventually.

The rooms themselves were ok. Not great, just ok. I agree with another yelper about the condition of the windows, they were really dirty. And the views are not great from any of the rooms. The room was clean, but they seem to have problems with burned out light bulbs because both rooms that our group had had at least one lamp that didn't work.

One night we decided to get dessert from room service. Ok because, their "24 hour" cafe is closed after 2pm!! WTF????  Anyway, not wanting to schlep down the strip for a slice of pie we opted for room service. They told us it would take 30-40 minutes for a couple slices of pie and some coffee. They lied. After 50 minutes we called and were told our order was on the way up. Again, they lied because it was another 15 minutes before it came. I will say it was some good dessert but my goodness it took forever.

The casino is pretty small but they do seem to have plenty of tables and definitely enough slots to go around. My only complaint about the casino is the live music they have every night. I enjoy live music, don't get me wrong, but in such a small place having a live band basically in the middle of the casino is a bit much. I prefer to enjoy the music and then be able to step away and do something else after awhile, but due to the location of the stage in the casino you're pretty limited on where to go to escape it.

The Steakhouse: If this review was only for the steakhouse it would be 5's across the board. You have to know that the restaurant is there, it's tucked pretty far back in the corner. Without a doubt, one of the best dining experiences in recent memory. Our server was on top of it but not in our face. The food was perfectly prepared. It is on the pricey side, everything is ala carte, but if you go in knowing that there won't be any surprises when you look and the menu or the bill. Everyone in our group enjoyed their meal. One had halibut, which looked scrumptious. One had pork chops, one had filet mignon and one had prime rib. Then we ordered a dessert which was spectacular. I highly recommend the Steakhouse at Bally's.

Would I stay here again? Probably. As I said at the beginning, for the price you can't beat the location. It's not Bellagio or Wynn, but it also doesn't carry the same price tag. Basically, you get what you pay for at Bally's.

Worst experience ever. 

We are here for a dance competition and we go out to the pool. My cooler got stolen. The people giving towels as you walk in tell me there's nothing they can do. The security guard is rude. Yells at me when I made a mistake and mixed up the colors of my luggage so. Instead of two blue and a black I reversed it. Sorry that I was all upset about me stuff. I'm human. 

Tells me they check room keys to everyone walking in but the three times I had gone to the pool not once was I check. Make me feel like I'm wrong. They tell me the police is the only one who can review videos but then tell the police there are none. What is that about. 

My camera, phone, team uniform all get stole and I don't even get as much as an apology from security or the manager. The ones who were at all sympathetic were the valet guys. Whats that about that they won't even check security cameras.  I'm left with no credit cards and no money and they didn't even offer a free comped meal. They comp all the time.

My daughter team wins first place and I can't even celebrate because of the treatment I received. I know my stuff is gone but they could at least pretend to care about the guests. I have not felt at all as if they care. 
NEVER STAYING HERE AGAIN.

I'm a fan of Bally's :) 

I've stayed here twice (once with family and another time this past weekend with my friends) and it's been a pleasure staying here because it is located in the middle of the strip and it's not a confusing hotel to find your room.

Our room was nice and clean with a view of the strip looking toward Palms. The bathroom was big and everything was organized neatly.

Only downfall about Bally's is it doesn't have an nightclubs or dayclubs. 

Bally's is good for having a place to pass out, get ready for the day\/night, and watch Jubilee! (but with people ages 18+ because the women do go topless lol)
Bad service, rest is ok. Especially the front desk people not very friendly and service oriented. My first and last time probably

I got a great deal using my Total Rewards card (70% off the room!).

I upgraded my room to the suite which was only $50 more per night and almost 250 square feet bigger.

They have a lot of table games that i like at $5 minimum but i can't seem to ever win. I guess the phrase is always true here... "the house always wins".

Good location smack dab in the middle of the Las Vegas Strip!

Only stayed here once, got the room comped. & what a nice room it was. The hotel was in a great location being it was near most the other big hotels & plenty to do in the area, food, shops, casinos. If you like to gamble then get your rewards card cause I get lots of offers for events & exclusive deals. I would definitely stay here again..

I live in Las Vegas, but when friends come to town we typically stay at a hotel. Bally's has been one of my go-to hotels. The rooms are very clean and you get a lot for the low price. I've been on floor 20 & floor 25, the rooms were different from each other (one had a sofa, the other had a chair thing) but both had a lot more room than I had expected.

My shower\/bath were combined, there was no mold. Everything was very clean. The layout of the hotel is nice and pretty easy to navigate. Parking is included with your resort fee, as is wifi. (It does explain this one the paper you get with your room keys, but the way it's set up online it makes it look like it's going to charge you an additional 14.99 for wifi. If you've paid the resort fee, you've paid for 2 devices on the wifi and will not be charged extra.)

I was able to pay cash for my resort fees, which was nice as I had recently lost my debit card and wasn't sure how that was going to work.

Customer service was always great. Friendly, polite, straight to the point. At a lot of hotels I've found that their customer service has been extremely lacking or it always seems like you're a hassle to be checked in\/out. This wasn't the case at Bally's at any time I've stayed there. Would definitely recommend and will definitely be back.

Hotel needs remodeling. It's one of the oldest hotels on the strip but a benefit of it is that you can walk to the strip from the hotel. 

The bed frame cut me and my husbands foot. It's metal and it sticks out to poke you! So painful! I can't believe that's even allowed in hotels! It's a safety hazard. 

They did have nice musicians singing at night which we enjoyed.

Hotel is located in a good location- right in-between the areas that have low table minimums and awesome food options. They've redone the outside of the entrance to include a bunch of "box shops" and a Starbucks to make the long walk not so boring. Good move on their part! Decent view!

The cons?
1. The cable is horrible at this hotel. You get 1 channel that someone between the age of 20-30 would watch, VH1. (I don't even watch that channel, but that was all there was) The rest are in Chinese? They definitely need to upgrade that because on a hot day, sometimes you just want to go, relax and watch some decent TV. Can't do that here. If you have 3 flat-screens in the suite and bad cable, what is the point? 
2. The rooms are awkwardly set up. We got upgraded to a suite but it was SO large and the AC only worked on the bedroom side of the room. You have a nice seating area and a huge dining table to eat at, but the tiniest fridge and nothing else. In most of the other suites I've been in, if you have a dining room, you at least have SOME kitchen utensils or a mini-kitchen to cook a little at. Not the case here. 
3. The safe is hidden in a nightstand drawer? It took us forever to find. Not in the closet, per usual. 

Not sure if we'll be back in Vegas, but we don't usually stay at the same place twice!

This was the third time I have stayed here over a 5 year period.  It has always been on a business trip for a trade show.  I like the place.  It is nicer than where I stay normally but the group rate brings it into my price range and it is easy to catch the monorail to the convention center.  The room is comfortable to lounge in.  One time my sister stayed with me a night and when she had trouble getting a computer connection the tech worked with her for about a half hour getting it resolved.  And he was friendly about even though she wasn't.  This stay they didn't have a 2 bed smoking that I had reserved so they bumped me up about 10 floors to the Diamond level for the same price and I got a view of the strip Northward.  They used to have a really good buffet, but no more.  I have tried every method suggested to get a receipt for the business expense using quick checkout and failed.  This time I just went and stood in line and checked out the old fashioned way and got a receipt.  I am sure I will stay here again in 2 years for the next trade show.

4-stars for this hotel. I know, I know--hear me out first. Bally's does not have the same name recognition and prestige as Caesar's Palace, the Venetian, or the Bellagio; however, you have to consider what you are looking for. Please note this review is long. 

LOCATION: The hotel is in a prime location, right in the middle of The Strip and near many other major hotels. Bally's is connected to the Paris Las Vegas Hotel--go through the casino (past the poker tables) and you'll see the path to Le Boulevard. Planet Hollywood Hotel, the Miracle Mile Shopping Complex, the Cosmopolitan, ARIA, the Cromwell, the Flamingo, Nobu, the Bellagio, and Caesar's Palace are all accessible with a pretty short walk. The latter two are accessible by taking the bridge in front of Bally's, which leads to Via Bellagio--inside, you turn left\/straight to reach the Bellagio and right for Caesar's. Other hotels are not too far away either--you just need to walk a little bit further. Food (casual and upscale), booze, boobs, and casinos are all within walking distance. There is a CVS right next to Bally's (at the S Las Vegas Blvd entrance).

PRICE: If you just want a regular hotel room at a relatively low price, Ballys is a great option. I paid an average $92\/day albeit with an ID.me discount for four nights ($102 without it), and it came with a "Strip view" (no extra charge--facing the Eiffel Tower Restaurant with other hotel towers visible). The large "resort fee" covers the different services and amenities offered, i.e., wi-fi. If you're looking for something a little more romantic, you might want to keep searching.
