My friend is a diamond status and let me tell you it's not what it's cracked up to be... He got me a two rooms that are connected one with a spa tub and a baday ... Yea sounds cool but the baday did not shoot water up and the spa tub took 45mins to drain BULL SHHHHHHHT... The maid services does not listen when you say come later. I think the pool was the coolest thing the  thing  te casino offered.. I told him u will NEVER stay at this casino again... Hard rock is so much nicer!!!!!!!!

I came during a busy week for CES so I understand the increase in room rates.  However they lack some basic amenities that even small hotels offer. You would think that with the rates they are charging during busy weeks they would at least provide a couple of bottles of water in the rooms.  People go there to spend more money at the hotel casino and restaurants so they really need to invest in better accommodations.  Wasn't too impressed.

This was my third stay on the Las Vegas Strip in three years, and, despite a few issues, it was, in many ways, the most pleasant stay so far.

So let's get the negatives out of the way first:

Issue 1: Finding the place. The biggest issue for us (and one that is completely outside the hotel's control) is that Bally's seems to be in the Twilight Zone as far as GPS is concerned. We came into Las Vegas from the south, and the problems began as soon as we exited the freeway. The GPS knew where the hotel was, but didn't seem to know anything about street names or where they were located. We were instructed to turn on streets with names completely different from what they were called on our Garmin, to turn on streets that simply didn't exist...it was totally insane. At one point we had both the Garmin GPS and Googlemaps on my phone going, and they each had different problems! At the end of a long day's drive, trying to navigate around the Strip, with all its traffic, with a constant parade of pedestrians in various stages of inebriation, and with two navigation devices that couldn't seem to navigate, we were totally exhausted by the time we finally managed to find our way into Bally's parking garage. So my first bit of advice to you is, if you plan on staying here, call the hotel for directions and use those rather than rely on your GPS!

Issue 2 (and this may be a deal-breaker for a lot of you): Smoke in the check-in area. If you've been to Las Vegas, you know that there's no way you can avoid walking through smoke-filled casinos, but most of the newer hotels have found ways to keep the smoke from leaking into the other public areas. Unfortunately, the check-in area at Bally's is every bit as smoky as the casino...possibly even more so, as there's no place for the smoke to dissipate. I smoked for 20 years, and am not normally bothered by cigarette smoke (in fact, normally I still rather like it) and it even got to me. If you have real breathing issues, and don't have someone else you can send to the front desk to take care of check-in, you might want to consider one of the newer properties on the Strip (or give Las Vegas a miss altogether).

OK...all that having been said, Bally's has a lot to recommend it. For one thing, to give credit where credit is due, despite the smoke, the check-in experience was about the best I've experienced in Las Vegas. We arrived at around 5:00 p.m., and there was quite a line, but things moved pretty quickly, and the woman who checked us in was both pleasant and efficient. I especially appreciated the fact that we were NOT given the usual Las Vegas lecture about how everything in the room is on a motion sensor and you'll be charged for anything that is moved. It was also really nice that the person who checked us in was able to give us very clear and accurate directions to our room in the Indigo tower (again, not always the case in Las Vegas!)

Our room was, in a word, amazing. Upon exploration, it was clear that is was actually the central common room of a multi-room suite (the doors to the other rooms were locked), but still...wow! It was HUGE! Quite possibly the biggest hotel room I've ever stayed in. In addition to our queen-sized bed, we had a nice, big sitting area, a full-sized dining\/conference table, a big flat-screen TV, a small kitchen area with a sink, a microwave and a fridge (NOT a mini-bar, but a real fridge that we could use without worrying about being charged for moving a soda to make room for our milk), a full-sized closet, a vanity area, and a very nice bathroom. Great view, too!

The bed was actually a Murphy bed, but was very comfortable (and didn't squeak, as so many Murphy beds do!).

We were surprised (and pleased!) to learn that we were able to connect two devices to the internet without an extra charge, as part of the unavoidable Las Vegas "resort fee" (that isn't usually the case, and I've often grumbled about having to pay for internet on top of the resort fee). The internet connection was fast and frisky...no problems there!

I have to say that, navigation aside, the location is great...right on the Strip, with an easy walk to wherever you may want to go.

So, is Bally's the place for you? Well, it is clearly an ageing (but well-maintained) property. It can be a bit difficult to drive to, if you rely on GPS. And there is that very smoky check-in area. On the other hand, it's convenient and comfortable, and the friendly staff don't treat you as if they expect you to steal the art off the walls, which is a pleasant change from my other Vegas experiences. Issues aside, I'd stay again.

Q: What do pathetic service, inedible food, and profound sadness all have in common?

A: They all live out their miserable days on this earth at Bally's.


This might have been the worst hotel experience I have had since the blood-soaked carpet incident that time in San Diego, but I digress.

The service at Bally's is service in name only.  Nearly every employee I came in contact with at this establishment was very obviously waiting for death's sweet kiss.  God knows none of them were interested in doing their jobs.  Case in point?  The maid took my ice bucket on the third night of my stay.  I figured I would ask for it back when she came back on day four...except she never showed up.  I got annoyed waiting, and tweeted at Bally's (on the expensive, but lousy Wi-Fi "service") about this.  They responded with a promise to take things up with management on my behalf...some 18 hours later, and 20 minutes after I checked out. Way to go, @BallysVegas.

An ice bucket wouldn't have been a big deal had there been a fridge in the room...you know...as you would find in any Motel 6 in the United States, but no.  No fridge.  Even more inexcusable?  No coffee maker.  Bally's is as anti-coffee as they are anti-maid service.  This place had fewer amenities than the jail cell in which i once spent a night in Naugatuck, CT (the birthplace of Naugahyde, no less).  But this irritation only tells part of the story.

I was at Bally's for an academic conference, which included meals.  I use the word "meals" only in the loosest sense of the term, as what we were served was almost wholly inedible. So inedible was it that, when presented with a steak I asked for a vegetarian meal.  They took my steak, mashed potatoes, and vegetable clump away and returned with...you guessed it, the vegetable clump.  Apparently mashed potatoes do not count as vegetarian fare anymore.  Alas..I went out for chicken strips.  Of the 500 people at the conference, mine was without question the best dinner anyone got.

And the people at Bally's know they suck.  They absolutely know.  How do I know?  When I checked out, no one even thought about asking me if everything was ok with my stay.  They are apparently tired of hearing the answers to that question.

This place was dreadful.  Do yourself a favor and go somewhere else.  Seriously...anywhere else.

In my first room on a non-smoking floor I had smoker for a neighbor and a connecting door. They then moved me to a room with a non working  phone next to the bed and a plug that had smoke marks around it.  To make matters worse it smelled even more of smoke. I'm afraid of where they will put me next if I ask for another room. If having s real non-smoking room matters to you pick another Hotel.

3.5 stars for Ballys. I like staying here because it's the middle of the strip and it's just easy to get around everywhere from this point. 

The front desk is always nice. The casino is friendly. 

The rooms are spacious and comfy. I don't mind either towers, south or north. The north ones are just a tad nicer. 

Not very expensive to stay here for the weekend. Bunch of roulette tables, two pai gow tables... and Paris is just a walk way.

My first time in Las Vegas and definitely NOT my last

We ended up staying at Bally's because they were offering 4 free comp nights. They even upgraded our room to a deluxe 2 queen bed in the north diamond tower. nice right? 

When we checked the room out, it looked really out dated and  a little dirty, bathroom counter was dusty, the floor didn't look like it was vacumed properly.. the windows were filthy, etc.. oh man i can go on!!!  :( Sure the beds were huge but the sheets and the covers looked like beds from "Boogie Nights" (yall remember that movie?? Dirk Diggler, Fat Gay Phillip Seymour Hoffman??... nevermind..) Anyhoo.. Long stories short. we were only there to sleep. 

The rest of the Hotel and Casino also looked pretty old and the whole entire room was filled with cigarette and cigar smoke!  DAMN it was hard to breath.

A few good parts about Bally's was their 2 Doller Tacos and their Two Dollar Tequila at Tequilas bar and grille!, How its right in the middle of the Las Vegas strip, and also their convenient walkway to the Paris Hotel and Casino!  

Was it a nice Stay?- Yes
Would i come back - Probably Not. I would much rather go to Caesars Palace or Planet Hollywood...

Pros: Location, and free valet. 

Cons: 
Hm where to start? 

The hotel in general is run down, the elevators were broken, the carpets stained, and very dimly lit. 

The staff is rude, and didn't tell me when they charged my credit card when I first arrived. Then after I complained they said it would go back on the card after I left or if it didn't to make my bank deal with it. 

The room itself was small and dusty. It had no microwave or mini fridge. The TV screen kept turning black randomly. All the outlets in the room were BROKEN and cracked or hanging off the wall. The shower water and sink water REAKED of bleach and chlorine. The carpet had large stains on it, and so did the bed sheets. We also had an outlet almost completely out of its socket hanging there behind our mini dresser between the beds COVERED in dust. 

So in total, the main reason we stayed here was the price. At the time we picked a cheaper hotel (but not that much cheaper!!) so we could spend more money around Vegas. But never again! Next time I am actually going to stay at a hotel that doesn't remind me so much of a desert MOTEL. Worst hotel experience of my life.

Don't judge a hotel by its facade.... On the outside this hotel looks, let's face it, UGLY. But on the inside it's one of Vegas' hidden gems.... The rooms are spacious, the lobby and casino are beautiful....  The outside of the hotel does not do the inside justice. it's also in a great location exactly in the middle of the strip. Great views.... And the one thing that made this hotel stand out more than any other was the amazing costumer service. Joey , a front desk clerk made my anniversary a great one. He was great. Ballys definitely has a costumer for life. And I'm also recommending  it to all my friends and family.

I waited until I stayed at ballys in Atlantic City before reviewing this.
The View from my Corner room in AC was lovely especially with the view of the beach and the rest of the city from the bathroom. Everything else about AC ballys was trash.

Back to Vegas
I liked the placement of the hotel and my room was very modern and just looked great. I was treated pretty well while there. The Casino was cool, they had A good amount of places to go eat.

The placement of this Hotel is its number one quality.
The shower head was still kind of nasty, but not as worse as Atlantic City
I had free wifi (Me)
Connection to Paris was great, because I liked their Casino more.
Nightlife overall is always on point. You can walk or go to anywhere else if not entertained.
The Front of the hotel was going through renovations on a shopping area in January when I went. It's probably done by now.

It's a solid hotel. nothing too bad but nothing too great.

Darn you economy!  The wife and I are really watching our pennies these days.  They sift through our fingers rapidly.

But when I got an e-mail offering cheap mid-week rooms in hot August Vegas, I knew we needed to get out of town.  A year ago, we had stayed at Bally's and upgraded to a jacuzzi suite for an extra $100 a night.  Those were the days.  So we booked a $59\/night room and headed out in the putt-putt Prius.

Now here's the trick that I learned from reading some other website.  When we got to the check-in counter I put a twenty right out on it in full view.  The sweet girl behind the counter decided to upgrade us to that same crazy suite -- this time with a view of the strip and the Bellagio dancing waters -- for only $50 a night.  Sold!  It was clean and great.  Jacuzzi was fun.

Other hotels look fun, and some of them are just as cheap, but we always seem to have a great time at Bally's, especially due to its sweet location.  We had a fabulous time.  Saw Penn & Teller, ate cheaply, got away with the whole 3-night vaca for around $1000.

Right on the strip. With good rooms and amenities. Good restaurants. Opposite Bellagio. A short walk to Paris. And you can really explore the strip staying here as well as lots to do inside the hotel.

I don't see why there's negative reviews . The room was clean , big and didn't look cheap . I loved the strip view and the employees were nice . Definitely looks better than Rio and Flamingo . Had a lot of shops nearby and was right at the strip to walk around . We hardly used uber . Casino and restaurants were excellent . I suggest trying taqueria tequila! The only problem I had was the wifi wasn't very strong , other than that I loved my stay and can't wait to be back in this hotel !

Stayed here for a quick getaway. Didn't except much because I booked cheap rooms on Vegas.com. Did the online check in and check out so I didn't have to deal with anyone, a blessing. The room was ok to sleep. We had no view which sucked but I didn't think we would. The location is almost center strip so that was a plus. If you need a quick getaway this hotel is good, just don't have high standards.

Beware of using the room phone- the rates are outrageous and  not posted. No coffee maker so you had to seek a cafe for breakfast. Comfortable beds  with a nice view.  The check-in was about a 20 minute line, but the check-out was easy with a key drop. It is close to my favorite feature in that neighborhood- the Bellaggio Fountain.

You get what you pay for. This goes to say there weren't any problems, just mediocrity. 

First, I made the unfortunate mistake to book a room with two queen sized beds WITH my parents.  You can guess what they did while I slept or shall I say TRIED to sleep. GAWD awful! Anyway, there wasn't anything wrong the room. 

Prompt room service
Clean room and bed sheets
Grandmother drapery
Bathroom essentials
BONUS: marble bathroom floor with plenty of large mirrors so you make sure you don't miss any angles. 

We paid $100\/night and it was just right. There wasn't anything special. I'm a happy camper when my things aren't stolen. Phew! The noise level was surprising quiet for a weekend. Overall, I'd say Bally's is the perfect hotel if you're 40 and on a trip to Vegas for a business trip minus all the crazy antics.

My group of friends takes an annual trip to Vegas which went on a two-year hiatus and resumed in 2009.  Each year, we stay at Bally's:  at first because of its central location and low rates, and more recently because we accumulate enough points to have the rooms discounted or comped.  It's a good "starter" hotel, and we find it good enough to keep coming back.

Both the hotel and the casino are the plainest of the plain, but they serve a purpose.  Usually we stay here and gamble part of the time next door at Paris.  On this trip, we did a four-hour stint at the Bally's pai gow table on Friday night which should set us up with the comps for next year.

There's really almost nothing to say about the hotel.  We've stayed here so much that the rooms look eerily identical; even last weekend, after three years had passed since I had been there, it was like deja vu.  The water pressure in the shower was really crappy this time; otherwise, it's just a hotel room.  You shouldn't be spending much time in the room anyway, right?

In a city where new and flashy are abundant Bally's is old and tired. Rooms seemed stuck in the 70's but where fairly clean and tidy.
The casino smells from al the smoke and the ventilation definitely can't keep up.
That being said I had a blast at the card tables, the dealers didn't take things too seriously and we had lots of laughs. Drinks came around at a good pace and I always got what I wanted.
Location is the strong point of this place but I did find myself on the other side of the strip quite a bit.

What can I say about Bally's that hasn't already been said?

You've seen one casino in Vegas, you've seen them all.
They all try to out-do the others.   We had a great room..
very large with two queens.   Marble all over the bathroom.
Our stay was cheap since it was comped.   Trust me, you
wind up paying dearly for the 'free' room.   We did not even
eat at the casino.. but we certainly payed our 'dues'!!  
I feel that they now owe me several more comped nights of
elegant slumber!  ;)

This is just one of several Harrah's casinos\/hotels in Vegas.
I would return...but you can lose your money just as fast in
Reno and Tahoe...and they are a lot closer!

I guess you get what you pay for! Ugh, this place is DISGUSTING. Got a regular room for about $90 on hotels.com. I was thinking it couldn't be THAT bad, but boyyy...it was. The carpets are so dirty that I will not touch my bare feet on it. The sheets\/duvet\/covers are those old style flower ones, which makes me wonder how long they've been there for. Sound proofing is HORRIBLE--I can hear people walking in the hallway outside and I can hear weird ticking noises while I was trying to fall asleep.

Okay, I'll stop complaining now. At least their bathrooms are decently sized!

Not a fan!
The little moving sidewalk that goes from the strip to Bally's is great....not when there is a creepy man riding it back and forth and staring you down as you head toward the casino!
The entrance is not friendly either. It looks like you are stepping into the dirty past.

Wasn't a fan. The tables are dirty, but they have high limits. The dealers weren't friendly and the people playing were just as odd.
Spent 3 nights with NO HOT WATER & NO help from the staff!! Horrible service! I would NEVER come back or recommend Bally's Las Vegas!!

I"ve got nothing but good things to say about Bally's.  

The rates are pretty reasonable for the most part.  Rooms are decent, clean and comfortable and the location isn't bad either.  

Is it one of the newer, posher properties on the strip?  No.  But it provides what you really need when in Vegas - a clean room\/bathroom and a place to pass out.

This place is connected to a not so nice shop\/bazaar thing and honestly it could do without it (I know it can't be helped lol)

I honestly loved the colors inside and the staff members that I had the chance to speak to were very kind and helpful!

I  would like to stay here someday!

Checkin is long and slow. That's accurate. The location is on the strip and generally its OK. 

We got a free upgrade because it was our honeymoon. We just asked nicely and got it. 

Didn't try the food or casino. So from what we saw it was good value. 

A few random black hairs in the bathroom dropped this from 4 to 3 because it shows a lack of focus on hygiene when cleaning. Dusty as well. 

But, for under 100 dollars and on the strip its worth it. But I wouldn't go again, there's nothing special about the hotel.

This review is on our staycation in Ballys from July 14 to the 18, at the south tower.
   Ballys best feature is its location. It is attached to Paris, across from the Bellagio and the Flamingo. Caesars Palace is diagonally across the street.
    Our south tower room was spacious and clean. Although the north tower is supposed to be the nicer of the two, the south tower has rooms that overlook the center strip. In my opinion, there seems to be little difference in the rooms themselves (we have stayed in the north tower). As far as safety, when we stayed at the north tower, security manned the elevator banks. Anybody could walk onto a south tower elevator. The room numbering is confusing. It took me a good few minutes to realize that room 6008 is on level ten.
    As far as Ballys casino,it served us more of a shortcut to Paris and the Strip, than a place to spend time in. It seems that Paris has more amenities than Ballys. Ballys does not have a big parking garage, and I parked at Paris. Ballys Coffee Shop closes at 2 PM, we ate in La Cafe. We'd have breakfast in Paris. We'd watch the dueling piano show in Paris. Ballys feels like an extension of Paris, and to me it seems like one large hotel.
  I recommend Ballys. And there ar no resort fees.

Ohhhh Emmmm Geeeeeeee! 

The Good:
Two things about this hotel that I can actually give them credit for.....
1) Housekeeping was AWESOME! They were very personable and even went out of their way to notice that we had champagne chilling and got us two buckets full of ice. They did this without our request, so that was very impressive and thoughtful.
2) BLT Steak was so much better than I expected. They try to get you to sit down for the full dinner but my fiancé and I went there for happy hour (a great decision) and the drinks were fabulous. Try the french fries and Jag drink, it comes in an art deco glass with juniper and is an all around juicy drink. 

The Bad:
1) Self parking is actually in the Paris hotel, about a quarter of a mile away from the Indigo tower. For all those ladies out there, the self-parking is full of dark corners so I would not recommend traversing there on your own unless you have your trigger buddy with you;)
2) Valet is another story. Every morning, I had to wake up around 5 to make it to work and even at THAT early time, they would not allow me to call down a few minutes ahead of time and get my car ready. I have stayed at many hotels here in Vegas and never have I been told that calling down ahead of time was not possible, even at busy check in time. Add to that the fact that there is usually only one person on duty to both give new valet chits AND take existing ones and you have a waiting time of around 10 minutes. Even checking into the hotel, I had to get out of the car and stand there in the heat and wait to flag down an attendant. 

The Ugly:
1) The hotel does not find it necessary to even compete with your mother in law's guest room as they do not provide a mattress cover and think it completely acceptable that bottom sheets remain untucked and scratchy as sand.  I would also not trust any of the covers or decorative pillows and blankets as neither looked like they had been washed in some time. The room itself was spacious and the bathroom, peeling wallpaper aside, was tidy and looked presentable. Don't forget that wifi and using their in room safe are anything but free.
2) NO FRIDGE
3) Unless you find ten channels and static reception enjoyable, I would recommend not turning on the TV. We live in 2015, if you saw your favorite movie on this snowy set of channels, you would have changed the station. Let's remember that we paid 130 dollars per night for this room. 
4) The doors and walls are paper thin, so when your overzealous neighbor wakes up at 5 to take a shower, you wake up at five and take one with him:)

If you find yourself staying here, I recommend not bringing anything that needs refrigeration, as obviously, it will spoil unless you do what we did and obsessively refill your ice buckets everyday. 

We did read the yelp reviews before staying here, unfortunately we came for work and didn't have a choice. If you have a choice, stay somewhere else, you will walk away from Vegas happy instead of trying to drink your trip into oblivion.

good luck!
The lower levels are so noisy. Everytime requested towers or soaps, had to wait one hour. The service is awful. The AC was broken and had to wait 8 hours for them to change a room.

It doesn't look great. It's not the newest and most renovated in Las Vegas. It can be quite smokey inside but you know what, for the price and location, you can't really beat it. 

The staff was extremely friendly. 

Sadly, my room, on my last day, I found an empty vodka bottle underneath my mattress, which worries me. I hope the staff changes their sheets because I don't understand how that was possibly missed!

when you're in vegas, you think of two things for the hotel you stay in, does it have a moderately tolerable bath facility and bed to snooze in and where it's located in the strip

ballys meets above criterias with a cheap affordable price, done deal, see you in vegas

Came here in the Casino's... no room.

Very old so it does smell like cigarettes like every casino but even worse... not as bad as Flamingo, but still bad. It's between Paris and Flamingo.

I got a feeling that Bally's caters to older adults - close to the retiring age because I saw lots of them when I came in here.

Bally's isn't the best hotel but it's not too bad. Especially for the cheap deals going on right now. The room I stayed in, the indigo king, was oddly decorated but very spacious. The tv was really small and only had about 60 tv channels, which half of those were advertising and\/or foreign channels. The pool wasn't bad either, pretty big and got chairs right away. You have to pay $10 a night for parking, which is ridiculous and they ended up over charging me on the kiosk, because they can't charge you at the check in desk, which doesn't make sense. The only really great thing is the location. Right in the middle of the strip. You can walk pretty much every where!

A great place to stay and explore Las Vegas. In my last few trips to LV, I would stay in Tropicana, Hooters, New York New York, and it would be very tiring for me to walk on the "The Strip" and back to the hotel. This time, I was with family and I decided to stay at the Bally's because of it's excellent location, which is right at the center of the strip, infront of Bellagio. So exploring the place wasn't that tough. Room service was excellent. They even got me a coffeemaker, although it wasn't included in the room amenities. Cleaning was more than perfect. Valet parking was always easy, available and quick. I didn't try the food there, but their casino is worth it. Even my Mom enjoyed on the slot machines and the Big Wheel. Overall one great trip thanks to the experience at Bally's

First night out on our great adventure; driving from San Diego to Hamilton, Ontario, Canada we stopped at Bally's. The hotel is a little dated and in need to updating. Check in was without effort; however, front desk staff lag behind the service we have received at other hotels in the area (Mirage and Ellara). Frankly, the staff were disinterested and not very helpful. The common areas are clean and hallways on the guest floors are quite wide to accommodate larger groups. The rooms are spacious and comfortably appointed although the carpets are worn, wall paper is beginning to peel and paint is chipped in washrooms. Nightstands are showing the ill effects of heavy wear. Regardless, the rooms are comfortable and let's face it, this is Las Vegas; how much time are you really going to spend in the room? The real attractions are the shows, food, nightlife, and casinos. So all considered this is a good spot for a quick stop over.

Been here a few times for conferences, so I know the conference center.  The casino floor is just about the same as most casino's of this size and is clean and spread out.  The employee's seem happy and enjoy what they are doing, at least today, they are friendly and talkative.

This was stop number two on the monorail ride today.  Easy access and quick walk in puts you close to the action!

This place does not deserve one star. It should be zero! I went there on Wed night in Dec and the line at check-in was quite long but only 2 check-in counter was opened. Service was super slow. On top of that, they also served people who cut the line first, not Professional at all. 

My friend and I booked 2 queen beds room and got 3 towels but we had 4 people. Does not make sense! 

Wifi works only for 2 devices. What if you come in a group of people? You will pay a resort fee for nothing. They are trying to charge you extra in every aspects.

WTFO? Called to make reservations to attend a convention being held at Bally's. We have a small 16b dog. Bally's charges $75 per night just for the dog. The room was only $89 per night. What a rip off. There are plenty of near by Hotels that either have no pet fee or a single $50 non-refundable deposit. Bally's is obviously mental. Won't ever stay or gamble here. One pissed off pet owner.
Don't understand how ballys gets any negative  reviews. Had a great time here. From check in to check out, I had an amazing time. Affordable prices for such great hospitality.

I've stayed at Bally's a handful of times over the years, and I keep coming back for a number of reasons.

Firstly, this hotel is perfectly located in the middle of the strip, across the street from the Bellagio and next door to Paris. The view from the rooms I've stayed in have been very, very good. When everything in Vegas is so much farther on foot than it seems, having a centrally located hotel with direct access to pedways is very helpful. Secondly, there are affordable options inside the hotel for meals and shopping, which is nice if you don't feel like spending big bucks on every single meal you eat while in town. Thirdly, for the location, the rooms are reasonably priced, especially weekdays. BE AWARE OF RESORT FEES; this is added to every day of occupancy, and for what, I don't know, but they are fucking annoying and should either be completely optional, or built into the rate of the room. 

Bally's doesn't get five stars from me because it isn't a five star hotel, frankly. The check in desk is 100 feet long but there were never more than three people total at any of the kiosks, and there were random employees talking and wandering around who didn't seem to care about or even notice the long line of patiently waiting customers. This looks bad for the hotel, and I heard more than one person say while waiting in line that this would be the last time they stay there. It's understandable. First impressions are everything. The people selling show tickets and timeshare tours were actually more helpful than the Bally's employees at the main desk, and the fact that they also look better than Bally's employees uniform-wise also is somewhat confusing.

Bally's also has no discernible theme and no personality. Compared to Paris, the younger, more beautiful sister, it's just meh. They need to brainstorm some concepts to make the place stand out. I think the outdoor mall is a nice improvement but it isn't enough. Bally's doesn't feel special; it feels generic.

Also, Bally's is starting to look run down and dirty, inside and out. The carpets are unforgivably dingy, and the details like dusting, wiping walls and glass surfaces aren't done thoroughly.  In my room most recently, I didn't really feel comfortable sitting on the couch or chairs without either putting a blanket or towel on them, because it didn't seem that the room was well cleaned. There were splashes of something on the bathroom wall, which I had to clean myself. The bed itself was a full-sized (ie underwhelmingly small) Murphy bed with ancient dust and dirt and balled-up tissue behind it. I mean, this is Vegas and the place is scuzzy, but the hotel room should be an escape from the scuzz, and not a source of it. I was also pretty shocked by how nasty the pool looks, like a bathtub with a ring of dirt around the sides.

To be honest, the next time I go to Vegas, I will probably stay here because of the pluses I mentioned, unless I find a better deal in a prettier or newer hotel. But if I do, I will also have to pray that I get a clean room with a decent bed, and pray that the pool is renovated by then.

Stayed for a weekend with friends with the awkwardest check in ever.

We checked in, went to our room and almost opened the door when..the previous hotel stayers walked out.

A few things to note:
1) this was at like 5pm..I thought check in was alot earlier than that?
2) They put us in a room where it wasn't recently cleaned (okay, with hotels..cleanliness is always an issue..but really?)?
3) If we didn't see the previous hotel stayers just wake out of our room..we could have just walked in and stayed in a room not changed out at all.
4) They said "Don't go in that room, it's pretty nasty in there"

2 stars down.

So of course, we ask for another room. We get an upgraded room for the same price we paid for the old room aka nicer accessories, same amount of space. I mean, after that our stay was fine, no trouble, yeah. Like overall, a cheap stay at a place with a fine location. While one of the older hotels, worth the location it's in on the strip.

But still...that was just so weird.

I like Paris hotel but it can be expensive. So staying at Bally's is the next best thing because it's attached to Paris. The lobby, restaurants, and shopping areas at Paris are nice. You actually feel like you're in Paris. 

Fitness fees are outrageous. Same goes for Paris's fitness area. 

But this is right in the heart of the best part of the strip. Everything is within walking distance.

For $150.00 for two nights.. pretty decent and on a BUSY BUSY EASTER WEEKEND... gigantic room, pretty decent also... this is definitely a place that you should check out because its in the middle of the major hotels... bathroom was clean, bed was clean, tube tv.. haha... in comparison to treasure island where my cousins and friends shoved themselves into a room that was a lot more pricier and you can probably fit two of there rooms into my hotel room at ballys.. thats how big our room was...

I was unsure whether I should leave 3 or 4 stars but I thought what the hell, so I just rounded up lol.  Anyway,  we read all the yelp reviews prior to arriving at Ballys at the end of July. We were anticipating trying the $20 sandwich trick, And honestly were a little nervous to try it but worked up the nerves and when we got there we did it! "excuse me  are there any complimentary room upgrades" as we slip a 20 between our ID and card. The lady was pleasant and didn't seem phased. She seemed like she was used to the 20 dollar tip day in and day out. We were booked for a standard room,  but she upgraded us to a Jacuzzi suite on the 10th floor! A little bummed it wasn't in the Jubilee tower, but hey I won't complain! It's a Jacuzzi suite!  The room was spacious! The Jacuzzi worked well. Yes,  the rooms looked dated,  like maybe they were hip and poppin back in 1991 and since lost their luster but oh well. We just needed a place to sleep. The room wasn't the most clean,  there were stains here and there.  (NOT on the bed)  but I'm not a diva nor am I the fucking queen of England, so I just ordered a second set of towels from housekeeping and we put towels down on all the chairs and the sofa and voila! Clean! I didn't complain once to them.  I was so happy we even got upgraded I just enjoyed our stay.   The parking is fairly straightforward.  Yes it cost $ for resort fees but so does everywhere else in Vegas.  I would stay at Ballys again IF we were on a budget. Next time I stay there though,  I will push my luck and ask to be upgraded to the Jubilee with my secret $20 tip!

This review is the first in a series of raves and rants regarding all of the casinos I've experienced in Vegas. Not that they don't have enough already. I just want to share dammit.

I've only been in the rooms here once, and that was 5 years ago, so cannot comment on it.

OVERALL VIBE

Ballys in perfectly located given it's appeal towards the budget minded folks. A popular spot for families, as well as younger groups. Very reasonable prices on food throughout the place. The decor is a little bland, but makes for a great casual environment to eat, drink, mingle, and even gamble. Not all ritzy and jazzed up, but not a dump either. A fun vibe with a less-than-normal-disorienting layout.

POKER

Poker room gets 4 stars. I frequent the poker room here due to the fact that it is a heavier concentration of nonsense players who are staying at the casino and want to give their luck a try. The poker room is well managed and a decent 1-2 game that gets pretty full around 7pm. They have a lot of bonuses, which contributes to the money on the table as the night progresses, but they also pull $1 extra per hand for it. It is located in the middle of the casino, so it gets a little noisy at times, but the bar is adjacent to it so no worries on cocktail service. 

DRINKS

They are stingy on the cocktails, even if you take care of the waitress. Fail. They do, however, serve cheap drafts at the bar closest to the entrance by the slots. The late night margarita specials are weak as well. Feel a sugar rush more than you do a buzz.

Also noteworthy is that the hot chocolate SUCKS. 

VERDICT

Again, I've never stayed here, so I can't comment on service or the amenities and all that. However, the laid-back, family crowd in a high traffic area along with decent cheap food options and a pretty soft poker game keep me coming back at least once a trip.

I have stayed here many times in the past on business. The hotel was the former MGM hotel many years ago. At one time it was the largest hotel in Las Vegas. The hotel is rather dated, but, I like its proximity to the monorail behind the hotel because my business was at the convention center.

My first night room cost was prepaid for $176.96. I checked in early around noon so I had to pay an early check-in fee of $22.40. My second night room cost including all fees was $264.32.

My king bedroom 1175 was average. The view was ok. The Wifi did not always operate smoothly. I really liked their laundered bathroom towels here. They were very soft compared to other hotels.

I stayed at Bally's recently and will definitely stay there again!

Rooms: I stayed in a standard room inside the newer tower (North Tower) located at the back of the hotel. It's about 450 square feet and included two queen size beds. Furniture and TV are a bit outdated, but I am very good at detecting rooms that are not clean. THIS IS A VERY CLEAN place to stay especially considering the "age" of the furniture, room, decor, and overall "age" of the casino. In fact, it was cleaner than the Rio suite I stayed at last time I was in Las Vegas. Tons of mirror space. hair dryer and iron that actually works. Amenities in the standard room include a facial soap, bar soap, Shampoo, and Body Lotion. Some rooms in this tower face a strip and it's a decent view. Unfortunately, I didn't get one of those rooms, but a friend of mine did and it was a pretty nice view! Strong shower faucet with great water flow. TONS of mirror space for ladies to put their make up on. Comfortable and spacious room.

Casino\/Gaming Floor: I have to give it 3.5 stars. A bit old and does not carry some of the newer machines, BUT REASONABLE RATES. They have slots priced on the lower end and my money lasted a lot longer here than Aria Hotel (and others). This place is a value for those that like to gamble with max bets on penny slots starting at 9 pennies! though generally speaking, they are about 20-30 and up to 50 cents for max bets (assuming 1 line play) for the penny slots. Sizable gaming floor for those that like tables as well. Fast lines and not too crowded.

Shopping: 2 stars if not 1 star. I wouldn't stay here for the shopping. It's an empty corridor, but at least Paris Hotel is owned by the same folks and is connected to Bally's. There are some shops along that corridor though it isn't THAT MUCH better either. 

Eating: Bally's has a Sbarro, Haagan Daaz, Ichiban (Japanese restaurant), and a Nathan's in its own food court. You can also eat inside Paris hotel and walk through the internal hallway inside the casino. It connects straight through and is very close to walk to Paris' Buffet.

Tip: Use the $5 off for a max of 4 people Paris Hotel Buffet and the total comes out to be about $14 bucks not including tip per person during the weekdays. Just as good as the Bellagio lunch buffet, but $10 bucks less with the coupon. They give out the coupons if you are staying at any of the Harrah properties and it expires at the end of March 2010.

Survey Opportunity\/TV Research: Earn $10 bucks by going inside a small market research room along the Bally's (almost dead) corridor. Get 10 bucks in cash for rating ads and television related market research. Easy way to kill some time and make 10 bucks. Takes about 30 minutes.

Check-In: I cannot complain. Fast and efficient. Friendly and helpful. Most importantly FAST. I had a smooth check in and my room was ready at 4pm (check in time). Check out town is at 11am.

Price: Excellent price. One of the best deals on the strip in my opinion. Not the best hotel on the strip, but for the price, it is a 5 star in itself!

Location: I am surprised and amazed at how cheap it is to stay here considering the hotel's central location. It's located center strip. I didn't have to take a cab my entire trip here. I walked to Venetian and as far as Encore and on the other end to Aria and Mandarin Oriental. Close to the cheap food\/food courts as well. EXCELLENT location!!! For shoppers, great location by two shopping malls (priced affordable for mid-America) including Planet Hollywood's Miracle Mile and Ceasar Palace's Forum Shops (the non LV side).

I LOVED my stay here and will come back for sure! Loved how the hotel connected to Paris and loved the people mover coming in. For those that want to take the Monorail, it's connected at the back of the hotel.

Stayed here with my BF 2 weeks ago and I must say not too bad for an older hotel along the strip. I honestly loved the fact that it's right next to Paris (which is beautiful and has awesome photo ops). Anyways the room that we had had no great views but basically we only used the room to shower and to catch some sleep and the BF and I were out most of the time so that wasn't a big deal for us. I loved the location of Bally's just because everything that we planned is closed by. We walked from Bally's all the way down MGM, Luxor down to treasure island. The 1 star is because somebody stole our do not disturbed sign lol.. I know it's not the hotel's fault but still that really ticked me off. They should have provided every room with do not disturbed signs that way nobody will be shady enough to steal somebody else's sign. Enough with venting, if you are looking for an affordable place and pretty awesome location to stay in Vegas this might be the place for you.
Very average,  not good or bad,  though the service was great!  The biggest benefit of this hotel is that is in the middle of the strip. Was clean,  just,  nothing social (got a suite)
This is solely on their Jubilee suite...it was huge and clean. I was surprised at how beautiful the suite was. I wish I took pictures because the view was beautiful too.

I had an absolutely great stay at ballys ! You will for sure get your money's worth at this hotel . It is one of the more reasonably priced hotels in Vegas which is a definite plus. All the staff were very pleasant and they were very proactive to accommodating us during our stay. I would probably want to stay someone where a little more upscale my next visit to Vegas but definitely a great money saver !

Pretty cool hotel that I spent very little time in. I had a nice sized room with a very comfy bed and reasonable rates. People at the front desk were very nice!
Not as popular or flashy as the other hotels on the strip, but I used it for what it was for: washing my ass, laying my head and changing clothes.
Not the best hotel for someone who needs to be away from smoke. The casino seems to be all smoking.

my initial reservation was to stay at Bally's Las Vegas. Upon arrival i quickly discovered that Bally's is a dump. 
The smell much like a convalescent home and concentrated cleaning products filled the hotel hallway. 
There were stains in the carpet for what seemed to be every 5-7 feet. When i finally entered the room the first thing i noticed was the big white stain on the carpet that could have easily been anything you can imagine that would disturb and make you instantly nauseous. The TV, furniture and decor were all beyond dated reminiscent  of an episode of the Brady Bunch where Alice may have been on vacation for a long stretch of time. The 1 highlight  i will admit was the spectacular view of the neighboring Paris hotel and the fountains at Bellagio, however this grand view was overshadowed but the disgusting grease smudges on the window. Needless to say....I wasnt going to stay here. After 2 plus hours hotels.com was persuaded to issue a credit which was applied to a night's stay at the beautiful Trump International. There was a price difference but that was no issue. 
The Trump offers a magnificent accomodation with  flat screen TV beautiful spa tub kitchen 2nd bathroom (offered in suites) and full kitchen. needless to say the Trump is the way to go. 
Thank you hotels.com for making the slow switch from slum to paradise even possible.

Stayed here for my 25th birthday. 

Room was great, it had a nice view. We got a great deal, because my friend is a member of their card system. 

Staff seemed good and the room service was the best- I had fresh towels all weekend!

The only thing I disliked was there was a lady that kept saying 'free rooms' next time we visit Vegas. She proceeded to led me to a gentleman at the desk and tried to convince me to put a strange down payment down that would last a year.

Overall, great experience. Hoping to be visiting this place every year!
The hubs is going to conventions here. We've not ever stayed here but the facilities are satisfactory and we like their sister hotel, Harrah's. No complaints.

Not Bad, Not Great. It is a pretty standard Hotel. 
The Steakhouse, though is great.
I would also recommend skipping the Jubilee Show.

What would've passed off as above average adjoining rooms all went to hell once our entire 12 man bachelor party crew set foot inside. I mean, the only thing noticeable was the hot tub (that no one used) and that each room came with a purty good sized tv that included all the basic cable channels. Bathrooms and bedrooms were nice 'n spacious...they had to be. And it was cool, yet probably necessary to have a coupla chairs and even a sofa in our main room. There's internet access if one is so inclined, as well. Even though the gambling, partying, drinking and all manner of debauchery took place OUTSIDE the hotel, we still tore that place up, without even really trying. As Wynona's character in Reality Bites said...we turned 'em into DENS of SLACK.
Got accused of stealing another customer's wallet by a blackjack dealer.  Had to sit and wait for them to review security to show that she was wrong.  Never gambling here again!

The Sterling Buffet is AMAZING! It is worth every cent. I highly recommend anyone visiting or living for that matter in Vegas go to this buffet. I never experienced anything like it.

To start off they serve you champagne. All you can eat prime rib, Alaskan king crab legs, caviar with creme fraiche, fresh oysters, shrimp cocktail, mini Belgian waffles, an omelet station, just to name a few...
Decent prices, spacious rooms, good location. Wouldn't mind staying here again.

My first Vegas trip stay, at the legal age of 21, was at Bally's.  Boy, was I in for an interesting weekend.  shauna a. is spot on when she said this hotel was not meant for anyone under the age of 40.  Whenever we walked through the hotel in our little dresses, we would get disapproving looks and long uncomfortable stares.  

The second we walked in the hotel, I knew this place was going to suck.  I understand the rooms have been updated, but when I stayed there, everything was so outdated. Not to mention dirty, with stains everywhere. The only good thing about the room was that they were pretty big.  We had two queen beds and more than enough room to probably fit a rollaway.  

You know how all the drink ladies in the casino usally wear something provocative? Yeah, they do that at this hotel too. Except they're older and at an age where something like that is totally inappropriate and awkward.  I'd always stare at the ground because I thought it was so weird!

We chose this hotel because it was cheap, the rooms were big, and it was in a great spot!  We were surrounded by Caesar's, MGM, The Mirage, Bellagio, etc.  Very convenient and I do believe you can walk from inside of Ballys directly to Paris.

Okay, so the room they stuck us with had an great view of Paris and the strip, even though it was not facing the Bellagio. From the room I could hear the water show at the Bellagio and every half hour it was Celine Dion and water canons erupting. For the price, we were right in the thick of the strip though. 

The rooms were very run down, we even had a few holes in the wall (I think where the mini fridge had been yanked from the room). The room was a nice size and very comfortable, but hadn't been updated since the late 80's. 

As for the casino, we didn't spend much time there. I felt that it was smokier than the other casinos we visited, and with Paris within such close walking distance, that's where we chose to donate our money. I think next time we'll spend a few more bucks and get a room somewhere else.

The indigo tower is old and not worth the cost. Maybe if we had been in the renovated tower we would have felt different. But it was drab and lacked furnishings. The suite was nothing special. Stay somewhere else or make sure you get the new tower.

Great rate.

Dreadful check in, almost an hour with so many problems including three credit cards not working but worked in all other casinos on strip and all shops in the actual casino. Ended up paying high ATM fees to pay in cash. Manager would not allow worker to input number of cards manually despite all ID's in place. 

Room great.

Shower poor.

Staff great.

Smell in casino is terrible. 

Pool is great.

In fairness to the casino, they reimbursed us one day's resort fee for the trouble. 

Location is perfect.

Good hotel, filthy rooms. 

Pros: Amazing location, old hotel but very spacious room, great view, relatively quiet, nice pool. 

Cons: Long lines for check in & out (but to be fair, they try their best to speed up the process with express check in\/out), annoying wifi limited to 2 devices at a time, but MOSTLY, what made our stay way less enjoyable was the cleaning.
Overall sloppy. There was some stains of alcohol or some liquid on a door inside the room, a ball of hair in the middle of the entrance that was never vacuumed in 3 days, coffee and coffee cups not refilled, ice bucket bag not changed. I expected more from this hotel on this point.

My husband and I stayed here for four days.  And although the room wasn't luxurious, it was clean and had an amazing view.  All the employees were very kind and courteous.  And while gambling there  waitresses came by every 15 minutes or so in the video poker areas. I gamble quite a bit and my honey plays the tables. He never has an issue getting drinks. But at other casinos there were quite a few times I can't even find a waitress although I have been playing for 5 hours or more at a time. I can't tell you how many times I have been in a 5 star casino , and am happy I carry my own water :)

I've never really noticed this hotel\/casino until my Total Rewards membership sent me free\/comped rooms. I stayed there for five days. Housekeeping was always there to clean. Location is good... On the strip and it's in the center. 

CONS: Valet was ALWAYS full. Their self-parking lot are not convenient to the hotel guests at all. EVEN THOUGH. The sign says "Valet Full. For hotel guests and Diamond members only".  I even said I was staying there and they said no. You basically park at the Paris hotel and have to walk 10 miles to your car\/room.

-Checking-In. The girl at the front, Jennifer, asked for my ID\/Credit card and she literally took my cards, faced up so the whole world could see, then went into the back for like ten minutes. My boyfriend had to ask the employee next to us to hand us my card cause the girl probably went to go take a dump or something. She did not tell us what room we had or anything. I know I request a certain view, but of course.. Didn't get it. Rude...

-Bell Hop: when we first got there, they took our luggage. We went to our room for 20 minutes..waiting and waiting. I was calling them and I believe a Maria or Linda from the Bell Hop picked up the first time, and later kept putting me on HOLD for a long time. Turns out our luggage was going through security. Like really? You couldn't tell me it was going through security. Instead the "B" Puts me on hold.. Their customer service lacks so much. 

-Another CON. Do not stay at the rooms facing Drai's. You will hear annoying loud-bass when you are trying to sleep. Like yeah, it's Vegas. But some people have to sleep too. 

-Room Service.. Lacks. Only serves until 6PM. 

Would I stay there again?.. Maybe, but only if my room is facing another direction. Or I'll just stick to Planet Hollywood.

We stayed at a two queen room in the north tower

[+] asked for a room upgrade during labor day weekend and we actually got it! from south tower to north tower, no extra cost either so yay!
[+] the room was pretty spacious
[+] Paris is attached and is right next door
[+] in the middle of the strip so it's a pretty nice place to be

[-] casino is on the smaller side
[-] faaaaaar walk to the pool

I would love to stay at Bally's again!

Bally's reminds me a little more of old school Vegas now that it is getting "older" compared to the newer, more glamorous hotels on the strip.  Great value for the rooms, and you really don't spend much time in your room anyway.  Wish they would update the rooms though.

Thank you Ballys for the awesome suite!!  Our suite was very clean and spacious!  I enjoyed playing at your casino, the cocktail waitresses came around very often to take our drink orders.  There were two staff members conversing on the floor when i stopped to ask a question and they immediately gave me their full  attention to help me out. Very friendly service! I will definitely be back.

The casino next door was having an outdoor dance party until 4AM right outside our room. Not only did Bally's never mention this they did nothing to try and help us get a new room. After passing the buck from employee to employee we ended up having to change hotels. Bally's is by far the worst hotel I've ever stayed at. Not only was their customer service Terrible they nickel and dimed you for every little thing. On the upside, the breakfast buffet was good.

Starting to show its age

I stayed at Bally's because of their location and price point.  However, it's time for another remodel.  My room was on the 19th floor and showed signs of wear as well as dated decor.  There were rips in carpet, shower head not secured to wall and A\/C not cold as it was set to 66 degrees on high fan mode.  

Housekeeping did an okay job but a cocktail glass from the former occupant(s) outside the door in the hallway never moved the entire 5 days of my stay (see pic).  I brought two more to my room from the casino floor and those eventually ended up in the hall as well.  

There was not a fitted sheet on the bed which caused the pad and sheets to bunch up and slip away from the mattress (see pic). Also, my room faced Flamingo road and all I heard were sirens and horns all night long.  You would think being that far up it would be quiet but no such thing!

For those who are into trivia, this is the location of the former MGM Grand which caught fire in 1980 killing 86 people and introducing a whole new set of fire safety rules in building codes.  In my opinion, I felt safe and comfortable during my stay so no worries about a repeat performance of that terrible event.

They did not honor our reservation that was made 3 months prior to stay in the Jubilee Tower (the nice one). They put is in the indigo tower (very outdated with a very firm bed). They stated that they needed to keep available rooms for their 7 star guests.
  Also, it has the oldest slot machines and smokiest casino of all the casinos we went to on the strip!

Nice clean room in Jubilee tower; great view of Paris Eiffel Tower. Comfortable bed and large shower. Friendly housekeeping. The place is good for a Vegas stay, fairly quiet and functional. I wish the bath towels were fluffier (kind of rough) and the valet workers were fairly rude for the whole 4 day stay (don't worry, one was very very nice when I left for good and gave a tip! I don't tip each time I get the car out\/in though. Sorry). Other than those complaints, the place was good for a hotel. Would recommend and return!

I should start this review by noting that I didn't have much choice in staying at Bally's. I was booked a room as part of a conference trip (ITC, if it matters) to present some slides accompanying a research paper submitted earlier. Anyhow, that's irrelevant, but just know this wasn't my first choice, even though I started with no preconceived notions.

My stay started with a lukewarm greeting at check-in. Upon arriving at the counter, and after checking that my room was pre-paid, I was informed that the only option for a room that evening would either be on a smoking floor (nope, not a smoker, and the casino floors in Vegas are smoky enough for me), or if wanted a non-smoking room, it'd be next to the elevators, would be noisy, and that I could check back the next day (the trip is three nights) for a better room. Whatever - I thought - I'm fine with dealing with some elevator dings and occasional people near the door.

The sounds audible inside the room are nothing like a few dings or people outside. It isn't anything like that. By "next to" the woman apparently meant - adjacent to and sharing a wall with - the elevator shaft itself. The room is arranged such that the headrests of each bed are bolted to the wall. That wouldn't be a problem ordinarily, however, on the other side of that particular wall is the elevator shaft. That wouldn't be much of a problem either, except that the elevators (there are three) are incredibly freaking loud and sound like a ski lift in the room. There's a continual series of three thumps as rollers ostensibly ride over a section of track bolted to the wall on the other side of the wall. Because the headboards are bolted to the walls, the bed and anything touching it vibrate accordingly, along with the floor and wall. It's like something out of a surrealist torture room instead of a Las Vegas hotel, I sh*t you not. As I write this, (from within the room, in fact) I've heard the elevator (or perhaps its counterweight, I can't tell) travel past the room 5 times. The sound is seriously surreal as well. It can also be imagined as the sound a deranged homeless man makes pushing a shopping cart filled with cinderblocks in circles over a set of three cement cracks. Except it Does. Not. Stop. Even at 3 AM. Nope. 

That's not really the only problem with this dilapidated room, either. The dresser looks like it has an incredible amount of water damage on the base and top, and cigarette burns. The room has a CRT TV (the south tower is obviously not renovated - thanks front desk woman for not giving north tower as an option) which sits on an equally battered looking TV stand that could collapse under the weight of a disapproving glance.

Oh and that isn't all either, inside the bathroom, there are several tiles missing at the base of the wall, with visible exposed drywall. As in, the entire tile is missing, and you can literally see drywall. The small trashcan was interestingly placed precisely to hide sight of this.  I've uploaded a picture to the gallery for your perusal, it's not hard to miss. There's nothing inside the room that wouldn't be much better without a fresh coat of paint, either. 

So why all this whining, didn't you ask for another room, you're thinking, right? Well, I did the next day - the answer? Not unless you want a smoking room. Pffft.

I just heard the elevator go by at full bore another time. \/sigh

Get bent, Bally's.

A bad first impression!  Stained carpets in the hallways and guest rooms, antiquated decor, and dank dim hallways.  The other reviews mention cleanliness, but my room was not.  If you must book this hotel, beware they will attempt to put $100 per day as a deposit on your debit card.  The only positive is the central location.  Avoid this hotel.

Hotel was fine. We stayed in the older, south tower. Next time, might pay the extra $40\/night for the north tower.  The room was very spacious. Bathroom was roomy, had a fan (always a plus).  Overall, pretty average.

Check in was easy, informational, and she was very nice. Elevators were very slow. Staying on the floor 19, but the floor was labeled 69. Not sure what the benefit is to have the numbers higher than the actual floor level.  Vending machine on out floor stole my money.  Like I wasn't already loosing enough at the casino? =)

Being connected to Paris Hotel was nice. Easy access the the yummy restaurants over there.  

Will I go back?  The next time one of my family members gets married at the Paris, and the Paris is $240 for the Saturday night, I would probably stay at Bally's again, but this time in the north tower.

*Review for a 5 night stay in May 2013* Great location on the strip, friendly and efficient staff. Not one of the fancier hotels but if you're like me and just want a clean place to sleep, shower and get ready this is a great find for the price. It's also very conveniently connected to Paris should you need anything more upscale restaurant or shop-wise. I've seen bad reviews on this hotel and experienced none of that. Only con would be a somewhat long walk from the actual strip into the hotel, but nothing terrible. The pool was very plain but efficient and played good music. I had no problems getting a chair on any day we spent there. Drinks are overpriced, which is the norm for any Vegas pool. We quickly learned they don't check your bag when entering so we brought our own alcohol. Don't forget to check out the tequila bar for $2 shots, beers and margaritas! For the right price I would definitely return!

My recent stay experience was pretty good. They automatically gave me the regular standard room in the North Tower that everyone here keeps on mentioning. This place is pretty spacious.

I believed the South Tower now has the newer\/modern designed now for additional $30\/night more. (I passed on it since it's just me and no one to really impress except my wallet=)

Anyways room was clean and the bed was really comfy

However my bathroom toliet was leaking pressure because it kept making a sound every few minutes. Yes the bathroom floor was mable and made it look more modern.

Overall for the prices and location as being in the middle strip and just a stone walk to Paris it was great.

I would stay here again.

Stayed here for a week. Isn't the most gorgeous place on the strip, but it ain't the dirtiest.
This place serves all the needs I have. clean room & bed sheets, working AC & friendly service. Casino is decent and the casino directly connects to Paris Hotel.
If your on a budget with your wife\/gf or just friends and want a nice decent clean room right across the Bellagio, this is your place.

I stayed here a few weeks ago when my friend was getting married at Planet Hollywood. We chose Bally's because it was a) reasonably priced and b) connected to Paris, which is next door to Planet Hollywood. We checked in and the front desk employee asked us if we would like to upgrade to a suite for $25 a night. Was going to pass, but he told us it had a Jacuzzi, steam shower thing-y (clearly I was listening intently), more space, etc. We figured for 2 nights, why not, that's nothing split between 2 people. I am SO glad we did! I can't speak for the non-suites, but I LOVED this room. Walked in to a long hallway, huge bed, sunken Jacuzzi, big vanity on one side of the bathroom, etc. It was sooo worth the upgrade. Our key was a sonovabeeetch at first but it just took a little fiddling with to figure out the system's quirks. If you stay here and they have a decent rate on suites, go for it! Our room was in the South Tower, which is the BEST area of the hotel to stay in for convenience's sake - if you look, there are other rooms that are wayyy further back. Let's be honest, nobody wants to be that drunk beezy stumbling an extra mile in heels at 5 AM (and this, ladies and gentlemen, is why I wear flats in Las Vegas).

I actually didn't know that this hotel was located on the strip, so I was little surprised when I got there and it was right there in Las Vegas Blvd. This hotel wasn't the nicest, but it was very comfortable and the room was huge. I did have a lot of trouble checking in just because the line was super long, but other than that I was not in my hotel room that much so it was perfect.

Bad customer service. We checked in monday. Asked for a fridge because we have a baby. They said we gonna put you on the waitlist for a couple days !!! Room's AC was not working. Also i asked for a a strip view room when i made a reservation, the representitive told me we gonna be able to do it mostly because its not a weekend. when i got there they told me its 50$ extra per day !!! Staff in general was Rude. Please smilee you are in vegas where customer service is priority. Iam a manager so i know what iam talking about. The folks at Ballys needs a lot of training in customer service. Its an experience wont happen again for sure

For a cheap but clean room in the center of the strip within distance to everything you can not go wrong. Our last stay we had a King size bed in the indigo tower and it was very comfortable. This time we had two queens and they are like being back in your teenage room on a hand me down cheap mattress, the body just doesn't adjust to that anymore. The casino isn't great as far as slots but it's always active and the black jack tables are pretty fun. Seems like one of the least ventilated hotels and you can smell smoke even in the non smoking rooms.

The Bally experience, Its one of the best location on the strip across from Caesar, near MGM ,Mirage and Tresure Island. the room was excellent looks like new we were in 926 no noise or loud ice machine near by, and best of all about $50 on a weekday. as for gambling, downtown has better odds, the super casino is alway higher odds against the players.

This hotel straight up blows. Our key card wouldn't let us in our room. I'm done for the night and I want to go to sleep. But no, I have to wait in the mile long check in line again. Every phone number on the website hangs up on me because it's after hours. It's Vegas! There are no after hours! The carpet in the hallways is dirty and depressing. The bathroom has so much chipped paint that it looks worse than the crappy apartment I had. I'm never staying here again. Happy birthday to me, I guess.

We stayed her for our little Staycation night. We got there about 4:30-5pm, enough time to check in, relax for just a bit and then off to dinner before our show. We parked in the back lot, stupid because didn't know better, and since it was just a night we were only lugging around two overnight bags but the walk, otherwise fine, with bags it's not. We couldn't figure out that maize of construction to park in the garage we circled it twice before giving up and listen neither of us lack common sense. Anyway, so on the front desk, gosh! I haven't stayed on the strip since before I moved here and really the check in line at that time! I thought by then it would have been shorter nope! We didn't have time for that s#&^! So back to the car with the bags. **enter long story of our fun night** *Back at the hotel, I wanted to be able to come back to the hotel to crash out from a drunken state and not have to worry about 'business' So I bucked up and tried to act normal. Since we couldn't wait prior, were checking in at about 2am or something late. "We upgraded you to the newly renovated tower" Oh sweet! No! It was right next to the elevators. They didn't have anything else available because we were the late checking in. So we had not choice to deal with it. It ended up not being that bad but remember the drunk part....

The room itself was nice, it was clean and upgraded and we had a great view of the Linq and surrounding sights. There was a little grim in the sink that you could only see while sitting on the toilet. The bed wasn't super soft and comfy like I prefer a hotel bed to be, it was on the stiff\/hard side but not unbearable. 

The thing that got me was that when I booked my room I got a $25 food and beverage credit. After we check in we went to the Mexican restaurant that they have there, Tequila Bar & Grill. I charged it to the room per the manager of the restaurant. We dropped our keys in the express check out. And the next thing I know my card is charged for the food! Grr! The line in the morning were check out and check in and slow just like the night before! So now I have to go out of my way to make the phone which is painfully impossible to get a manager on the phone. Which at this current time I've actually given up on. I need to call again, but I hate tracking someone down. Anyway, the point is when I asked to speak to a manager and the phone rings and rings and they don't even have a voicemail! Is there someone even on the other end? Did you just transfer me to a phony phone number? Lame! 

When we returned to the hotel at night we valet not wanting to walk the walk with the bags again. In the morning, it took 15 minutes for them to get my car. There were people getting their cars that came up after us, we were about to ask about it but then we see my car. The attendant was nice and apologized for the wait that they had the wrong description\/wrong space of my car and he couldn't find it. Awesome! 

Can't comment on the casino or much else as that is all we did in the hotel that evening.

I'll say this, there are some rooms there in a certain tower that shouldn't be available for guests. I checked in and the room was nasty. A\/C wasn't working right, hot and muggy, chipped old furniture, stains on the chairs, bed was squeaking and old... We asked for a different room, and they were about to give us the same kind of room in the same tower just 2 levels above! 

Finally, we were told that there was another tower that was newly remodeled, cleaner, only for a $50 upgrade. I'll say, it was awesome. Best view period, jet spa, the works. 

The reason for my low review is because they need to close down that ugly tower and remodel it.

This place is quite the mixed bag.  The good:  it's cheaper than other places on the strip and the room was huge.  The bad:  check in\/out lines are long and they nickle and dime you too much (want to check in before 2pm, that's extra; forget something, we can mail it to you for the cost of mailing +$5 handling) .  Overall I'd probably stay here again because I'm cheap but there place isn't going to wow you.

It was year 2003 in vegas with a couple friends stayed at this hotel.  They ended up giving us the celebrity suite for the whole time and it was awesome. We paid the normal price of a regular room, hotel treated us very well.  There was really nothing to complain about except the fact I didn't get the chance to  use our own gym in our suite.  The place outside does look outdated but our whole entire suite was clean and modern. Shower was all glass, granite bathroom, jacuzzi bathtub was huge. Bed was comfortable. That was important.

Hotel: $20 tip trick for an upgrade from a room in the south tower to a junior suite in the North tower for the WIN! Sounds like a big deal, it's not. It makes me wonder what the original room looked like. Our room was spacious and clean with a nice view but definitely worn. Not too shabby, just a place to shower and sleep nothing more. The 4 stars are for the overall customer service & location. We could easily get anywhere we needed to be from here by walking.

Casino: I'd stay away from the casino (especially the slots) I wasn't at all lucky here.
I enjoyed ballys. It is worth it to upgrade to the north tower. It is newer, nicer, bigger. Stayed here for bachelor party. 8 guys in a queen room

Ok I don't normally leave reviews but I think this place sucks. From the first night we arrived was a joke our room wasn't available the room we got was dirty house keeping left trash smelled so horrible. And I don't get why the hell they charge a resort fee for use of pool and gym  when the dam pool was closed and we don't use the gym so why do I have to pay a 35 dollar a day fee so  absurd. 
I will never stay in this crappy hotel again and I will make darn sure I wright a letter to corporate and that my friends , family never stay here as well  thanks for the crappy expensive room ballys.

If they had a zero star option I would do it! By far the worst hotel I have ever stayed at in Vegas!! First we reserved a room with a king size bed two weeks in advance. When we got there they only had a queen available. The receptionist was a complete bitch!! When we got into our room it was a pull out bed coming out of the wall. The carpet was disgusting, there was hair all over in the shower and the counter top was as if someone spilled drinks all over it and was never cleaned off! We went to try and switch rooms and the supervisor  said there were no rooms available (which was a lie because my brother checked in at the same time and they offered to upgrade him to a suite or a king size bedroom for free!!!) so the supervisor said he would send someone to clean the room immediately. Two hours later we go back to the room and no one had come to clean at all!! The next day they finally let us have a different room! My whole family was staying there for the weekend and we will not ever be returning to this dumpy hotel!!

First off, I don't gamble. Even in the midst of a gaming paradise, such as this. I was here for a show, and had about an hour to kill after exchanging 1\/2 price vouchers for tickets. 

This was after dinner, and my husband and I weren't looking for alcohol, just water. We ended up paying $9 for 2 20oz aquafinas from a hallway concession by The Paris. The lady was so sweet, she offered me a bag for the super hot, but impossibly uncomfortable Betsy Johnson stilettos I was now carrying.

Still about 15min away from doors opening, we sat at the machines. Didn't spend a dime, but a cocktail waitress graciously brought 2 coffees. 

When the doors finally opened, at least 2 ushers asked us where our seats were. We meant to buy mid-range ticket, but the girl at the ticket booth misunderstood and sold us the least expensive seats. No big deal, thought we'd be able to upgrade at the Bally's box office, but not. The second usher was trying to up sell us, I thought, nope he just upgraded us to a stage-side table! That was very cool!

The show itself was good, classic showgirl\/ showboy number with lots of music, choreography, sequins, and tasteful nipples. The story line was kinda weird though. Getting the upgrade was the best part, definitely a fun experience.

Am I in China? 50% of the guests here are Chinese. I went here to see Jubilee (which was beautiful, but horrendously boring), and I seriously felt like I was in a Chinese hotel. There are Asians running and yelling across the casino floor, literally. 

After the show, some white trash and bf were screaming in front and the girl collapsed close to me with a bloody leg and continued to scream. Then what happened? Nothing. No one from Bally's helped.

Never again.

Quietly, a bargain on the strip. The rooms are large and clean. It is connected to the Paris, so it does have things to do on the shared property. And it is in the best location, center of the strip. Of the cheaper hotels in Vegas, this is the best.

This is your typical mid-line casino. Nothing really special about it. The best thing we enjoyed about it was the $1 margaritas (even though they were barely drinkable) and the $1 tacos (which were just a step above taco bell). The only reason we came here was for the Price Is Right Live show. Did not stay after the show because we felt kinda cheated.

Considering it was free, I cannot complain too much, and Jimbo the blackjack dealer is fratty and awesome, but there's a good chance if you go to the pool you'll be the best looking person there. Ain't nobody go got time for looking at that for am extended period of time.

I was in Vegas for a conference held at Bally's.  At first glance, my room seemed really nice.  I had a king bed and an adorable blue velvet settee and matching ottoman.  We've all heard the rumor that casino's pump in oxygen to keep people awake and at the tables, but Bally's further incentifies you to stay awake by having really uncomfortable beds.  There is no fitted bottom sheet, so after stumbling into bed after a late night, you may find that you've peeled back one too many layers and are face to face with bare mattress.  Yuck.  Waking up in a tangled mess of top and bottom sheets is not a good way to start the day.  The mattress was cheap and uncomfortable, and I noticed small tears and stains on the sheets.
  
I had a nice window and balcony, but the sliding glass door was bolted shut.  Probably a good idea, but it sure would have been nice to have some fresh air.  The curtains were also stained with what looked like but I hope wasn't smeared blood.  I did have a small refrigerator in the room with a large dent in the middle.  It woke me up several times throughout the night with strange loud noises.  

The upside was the staff I encountered were all very nice and helpful. Also, it is well located on the strip. I've stayed at some pretty raunch hotels in the past, and this definitely wasn't worst, but I was certainly looking forward to my last night.

Love Ballys! The value way exceeds the price. Everything was great! Where to start...first the music in the lounge is fantastic with Resa singing a Whitney Houston song so beautifully. Great dancing and music choices. I love that they have a coffee bar open 24 hours. Housekeeping does not miss a beat which is rare in most hotels. The hotel is easy very user friendly.
